specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: ITLingo/GenTechnicalDocs: Produção Automática de Documentação Técnica
objectives:
No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo/RSL (Requirements Specification Language) tem sido definida uma linguagem textual para especificação rigorosa de requisitos (linguagem RSL), cuja versão preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de  https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL.  
No âmbito deste projeto pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas da engenharia de requisitos, modelação de sistemas, validação e produção automática de documentação técnica. 

Este projeto deverá desenvolver-se ao longo das seguintes fases:
A primeira fase consiste na análise e definição do problema e na investigação sobre a iniciativa ITLingo, em particular a linguagem RSL e as suas ferramentas e tecnologias de suporte (e.g., ITLingo-Studio, Xtext); bem como o aprofundamento do corpo de conhecimento relacionado com a engenharia de requisitos e da documentação técnica de sistemas. 
A segunda fase consiste na definição e implementação de mecanismos de transformação de especificações de requisitos (em RSL) em documentos técnicos que integrem também modelos visuais de sistemas de informação (e.g., em UML, BPMN, IFML, Wireframe). Estes modelos visuais deverão ser integrados em documentação técnica de requisitos de acordo com templates predefinidos em ferramentas de Office (e.g., MS-Word, Excel), e por esta forma complementarem as especificações textuais.
A terceira fase consiste na definição de estudos de casos (i.e., especificações de requisitos para aplicações/sistemas concretos) que permitam a consequente avaliação e discussão dos resultados produzidos. Este trabalho deverá ainda ser avaliado e discutido com base de trabalho relacionado.

Referências adicionais:
https://www.researchgate.net/project/ITLingo-Specification-Languages-for-the-IT-domain
https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL

title: PROJETO: Identificação de expressões fixas em texto
location: Laboratório de Sistemas de Língua Falada - L2F (INESC-ID Lisboa)
objectives:
Pretende-se introduzir um conjunto de melhorias um módulo que gera regras que identificam expressões fixas e ditados populares. 

As alterações a introduzir incluem: (1) todas as conversões usadas na geração das regras têm de estar numa tabela (declarativo); (2) aceitar coordenação de um constituinte; (3) aceitar construções do tipo predicativo do sujeito; (4) aceitar contentores (por exemplo, "as *medidas* dos professores").

Deve ser anotada um corpos com as expressões fixas para permitir uma avaliação do desempenho (precisão e abrangência).

Na avaliação deve passar a permitir:  (1) fazer uma comparação com a última avaliação: novos falhanços, novos erros; (2) indicar a razão do falhanço (não existe dependência, traço, …); (3) escrever o resultado da avaliação e a causa do erro no excel usado para gerar as regras que identificam as expressões fixas; (4) gerar automaticamente frases sem um dos elementos fixos; (5) avaliar o desempenho num corpus anotado manualmente (com estatística dos tipos de erro).
requirements: O aluno com perfil para este trabalho deve ter obtido classificação superior a 14 na disciplina "Língua Natural" do MEIC.

title: [Dissertation] Understanding the Evolution of the Web
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project will be carried on in collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Web applications play a prominent role in the Internet of today. They run on multiple platforms and devices and are increasingly used by people in their everyday lives to accomplish all sorts of tasks, including e-mailing, word processing, online banking, among many others. 
In order to make web applications behave consistently across all platforms, the World Wide Web Consortium [1], W3C, has long been establishing web standards that precisely describe how web applications are to be loaded, executed, and displayed. Such standards are accompanied by official test suites, which browser implementations use to check their conformance with respect to each standard.
One of the most popular web standards is the Document Object Model, DOM [2]. First published in 1998, the DOM was designed to cater for the programmatic manipulation of HTML and XML documents. Since then, the standard has been steadfastly growing. Starting with DOM Core Level 1, which only describes the various DOM node types and the methods they expose, the DOM has grown to include separate specifications of several additional HTML features, such as Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and UI Events.
In contrast to JavaScript, whose standard is fully adopted by most browser vendors, the degree of adoption of the various W3C standards is highly variable, with browsers explicitly opting not to provide support for novel standard features. For instance, Internet Explorer does not support the Shadow DOM [5], an extension of the DOM API that allows for CSS scoping and DOM encapsulation.
The **goal** of this thesis is to study the adoption of novel DOM features by web applications in the wild. More specifically, the project will consist of an empirical study [6, 7, 8] performed on Web applications that make use of the various APIs defined in the DOM Living Standard. It will comprise the following three main tasks. First, the student will develop an infrastructure to mine applications from software repositories in GitHub, identifying those that make use of any of the DOM APIs. Then, the student will implement a simple static analysis tool to automatically label each web application with respect to the DOM features that it uses. Finally, the student will classify the collected data according to the standard’s versions and potentially identify non-popular features. 

[1] W3C https://www.w3.org
[2] DOM Specification. https://dom.spec.whatwg.org.
[3] https://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-DOM-Level-1-19981001/
[4] Choudhary, Shauvik Roy, Mukul R. Prasad, and Alessandro Orso. "Crosscheck: Combining crawling and differencing to better detect cross-browser incompatibilities in web applications." 2012 IEEE Fifth International Conference on Software Testing, Verification and Validation. IEEE, 2012.
[5] Shadow DOM. https://www.w3.org/TR/shadow-dom.
[6] Kitchenham, Barbara A., et al. "Preliminary guidelines for empirical research in software engineering." IEEE Transactions on software engineering 28.8 (2002): 721-734.
[7] Shull, Forrest, Janice Singer, and Dag IK Sjøberg, eds. Guide to advanced empirical software engineering. Springer Science & Business Media, 2007.
[8] Easterbrook, Steve, et al. "Selecting empirical methods for software engineering research." Guide to advanced empirical software engineering. Springer, London, 2008. 285-311.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Increasing privacy in interactions between robot and humans using Blockchain - Impact in the business processes of an healthcare environment
objectives:
Os sistemas de informação hospitalares apresentam um conjunto significativo de desafios para o Engenheiro Informático. A privacidade localiza-se, hoje, no topo destes desafios afectando uma multiplicidade de pessoas que trabalham, ou usam, cuidados de saúde. Por outro lado, os robots quando inseridos nos ambientes hospitalares introduzem uma capacidade acrescida de benefício social, mas também de recolha de dados em grande quantidade. Estes dados têm que ser tratados atendendo aos requisitos legais, p.e., impostos pelo RGPD. Assim, torna-se clara a necessidade de encontrar novas soluções que suportem esta preocupação. Neste sentido, o Blockchain é uma solução que contem propriedades compatíveis com os requisitos de privacidade impostos pelo RGPD. 
Em específico pretende-se explorar os processos de negócios novos e a adaptação que é requerida com esta abordagem, para identificação do impacto social, tecnológico, e de gestão bem como as limitações existentes na solução

Assim, são esperados os principais resultados: 1. levantamento de estado da arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial, tendo em vista a identificação exacta do problema a ser resolvido; 2. representação de um modelo conceptual que vise propor uma solução para o problema identificado; 3. utilização de um protótipo que permite integrar dados do ambiente com interacção social entre robot e humanos e a solução Blockchain; 4. avaliação dos resultados obtidos no ponto 3 como justificação para a correcta solução escolhida no ponto 2.; 5. publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

Androulaki, E., Barger, A., Bortnikov, V., Cachin, C., Christidis, K., De Caro, A., Enyeart, D., Ferris, C., Laventman, G., Manevich, Y., et al.: Hyperledger fabric: a distributed operating system for permissioned blockchains. In: Proceedings of the 13th ACM EuroSys Conference (2018)
Christidis, K., Devetsikiotis, M.: Blockchains and smart contracts for the internet of things. IEEE Access 4, 2292-2303 (2016) Gupta, M.: Blockchain For Dummies IBM Limited Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Inc. (2017)
Nakamoto, S.: Bitcoin: A peer-to-peer electronic cash system (2008)
Wood, G.: Ethereum: A secure decentralised generalised transaction ledger. Ethereum Project Yellow Paper 151, 1-32 (2014)

title: Dissertação || MaaS: Medclick platform As A Service
observations: Further details see  https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado
objectives:
Enquadramento: 
As growing costs pressure health systems, mainly due to an ageing population, the rise of the private medical service providers has been growing in Portugal. In 2013, nearly half of Portugal’s hospitals were private. Over the last ten years, private hospitals have grown in consultations, number of beds, emergency rooms and diagnostic tests. The number of outpatient medical consultations increased steadily between 2002 and 2013, from 9,8 million to 17,6 million visits, with private hospitals accounting for 5,1 million consultations, 29% of the total. 
The growth of private health insurance, reduced waiting times and advanced technology, are among the main growth drivers for private medical service providers.
Although major private medical service providers in Portugal have an electronic reservation system, the process of booking a medical consultation is generally a tedious process and always limited to the service provider’s ecosystem. 
MedClick provides a one-stop platform to book a medical appointment in a fast and user-friendly way, across multiple medical service providers. Whether on a PC, tablet or smartphone, patients can conveniently browse all available booking options, based on date, location, price, insurance providers, or customer reviews and recommendations. 
MedClick helps medical service providers increase the efficiency of their practices, by featuring an advanced platform to manage and explore scheduling flexibility, filling available time slots. 
…………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Descrição:
 
MedClick’s services are available online through a web portal and mobile apps for Android and iOS smartphones. 
Some healthcare providers, besides being available in a common web portal, also require a specific site. The goal of this thesis is to design and implement a “White Label” version of MedClick to support this requirement.
The major purpose of this thesis is, therefore to support MedClick in developing a whitelabel version of the MedClick Platform. This may be provided “As a Service” – allowing the customization of a set of features (e.g., company logo, name, colours, layout) and the selection of functionalities (currently available at medclick platform) that are each health provider wants to make available (e.g., general information and contact, appoint scheduling, no shows management, chatbot interface, symptom advisor, among others).
In order to provide MedClick As A Service (MaaS), each healthcare provider should be able, in a self-service environment, subscribe the medclick service, customize its information, and select the features that will be available in the healthcare provider site.
After the selection of features and the customization the MaaS platform will generate a customize version of the MedClick Platform available in a domain URL of the healthcare provider.
On the technology side, Component-Based Architecture (CBA) and Model-View-Controller (MVC) architecture present are widely supported and allow rich client interfaces, namely through  React, Ember or Angular frameworks. The thesis should propose a technological solution, scalable wide enough to cope with different requirements from health providers, recurring to code generation and portal bootstrapping. The portal customized features shell be deployed in a matter of minutes.
requirements:
Resultados Esperados: 1. MaaS Architecture proposal
2 MaaS prototype implementation
3. Paper Publication.

title: Project: Image Labeling for estimating carbon footprint
location: Work will be conducted at the Interactive Technologies Institute (ITI) of LARSYS - http://iti.larsys.pt
objectives: Despite the rising awareness and concerns about climate action people still struggle to understand how their actions and choices impact their carbon footprint. This project will develop a mobile application that combines automatic ML image labeling (e.g. google ML kit - https://developers.google.com/ml-kit/vision/image-labeling) with online databases which can estimate the carbon footprint of specific items that we possess or intend to purchase. The project will involve researching both the best ML algorithms and the open-source databases for carbon footprint estimation. It will then involve developing and testing a prototype with end-users in order to understand how effective the solution will be in helping people achieve sustainable choices in their daily actions.
requirements: Students should be familiar and/or interested in Android and/or iOS development. Basic knowledge of HCI and UCD methods as well as interfacing ML and image recognition algorithms. The project doesn't involve developing new algorithms but students need to understand how to use and apply these in a real-life solution.

title: [Dissertation] Coding the future data center networks
observations: Esta dissertação será orientada pelo Prof. Fernando Ramos, que passará a ser docente do DEI a partir do 2 semestre de 19/20.
objectives:
The ability to code network packets has been shown to improve a network's throughput, robustness, and security [1]. Given the fundamentally different packet processing required by this new paradigm, until recently it was impossible to perform network coding in real hardware, creating a barrier to its wide-spread adoption.

Fortunately, the emergence of programmable switches (such as Intel/Barefoot Tofino [2], the world’s fastest) and of a language to program them (such as P4 [3]) have changed the situation, and enabled very recently the development of the first network coding (NC) switch by our team [4].

In this project the goal is to design a high-performance, highly robust data center network that uses NC switches as their main building block. As part of the project the student will have the opportunity to work with cutting edge networking technology, including programming a Barefoot Tofino switch [2] using P4 [3].

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos (who recently joined the IST as Associate Prof.) and Muriel Medard (Prof. at the MIT, and a leading expert on network coding)

[1] C. Fragolli et al., “Network coding: an instant primer”, ACM SIGCOMM CCR, January 2006
[2] Barefoot Tofino: World's fastest P4-programmable Ethernet switch ASICs, https://www.barefootnetworks.com/products/brief-tofino/
[3] https://p4.org
[4] D. Gonçalves et al., Random Linear Network Coding on Programmable Switches, EuroP4 workshop, 2019
requirements: The students must have a good background in distributed systems.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Developing the new MACSec standard
objectives:
While SSL and IPsec allow to establish secure channels at higher levels, they cannot prevent or detect security breaches on Layer 2 such ARP poisoning. 
Media Access Control Security (MACsec) is a technology that enables secure communication for traffic on Ethernet links. MACsec secures directly connected nodes Ethernet links and it is able to identify and prevent most intrusions, denial of service attacks, man in the middle snooping, passive wiretapping, playback attacks and masquerading. 
MACSec is standardized IEEE 802.1AE hop-by-hop encryption that enables confidentiality and integrity of data at layer 2. It encrypts entire Ethernet packet except Source and Destination MAC addresses on any device-to-device, switch-to-switch, router-to-switch, host-to-switch directly connected wired L2 connection.

The goal of this work is to study, implement and analyze MACSec standard (or Cisco TrustSEC)
requirements:
The main requirements for the development of this work are:- security background 
- good programming skills

title: Projeto: Supporting Children's Mobility in Public Transport
observations:
This project is the result of an international partnership, which includes the Interactive Technologies Institute (PT of LARSYS), Instituto Superior Técnico de Lisboa (PT), and the School of Architecture at the University of Texas in Austin (US).
This thesis will be co-supervised by Claudia Silva (claudia.silva@m-iti.org), postdoctoral researcher at ITI / LARSYS.
objectives:
Since February 2017, in Lisbon, children aged 4 to 12 years are entitled to free public transportation at Carris (bus) and Metro (subway). This measure aims to: encourage inclusive mobility; promote the use of public transport among young people; create habits of use of public transportation from childhood; improve the quality of life of the city. We see this context as a real opportunity to understand better how ICT can contribute to the potential of engaging children in the use of public transportation. In doing that, our proposal is to explore a set of creative methods such as children’s map drawing activities and design innovation frameworks to inspire the creation of an interactive location-based system to help them to move around the city in a safe and sustainable way. 

The location-based mobile application should facilitate and assist children in their travel from home to school and vice-versa, allowing them to write notes about the trip and/or answering to simple questionnaire/tasks, receiving real-time notifications, and, eventually, including the possibility to share the trip with the parents.

The research and developments objective of this project are multifold: 1) to raise awareness of youth towards sustainable transport beyond the private family’s car; 2) to improve children security and parent’s perception of children security, 3) to enhance the travel from home to school making it pleasant and safe for children. Following this rationale, this project requires: a) creating a digital system, including a location-based mobile app that assists children in their travel from home to school and vice-versa; b) designing the system keeping into account data obtained using creative methods as participatory design and map sketching; c) deploying and testing the system using HCI methods, such us, focus group and experience prototyping.
requirements: Students should be familiar with standard web development tools and platforms in particular Javascript/Node.JS and HTML5, CSS3, to implement a cross-platform application. Students should be interested in Interaction and Design and Human-Computer Interaction techniques since the development of the prototype will require conducting participatory design and evaluation sessions with end-users, in this case children.

title: Dissertation: Blockchain Identity and Access Control Management
observations: Tema reservado para Guilherme de Seiça Ribeiro do Quental de Menezes, nº 76494
objectives:
The notion of identity is tightly associated to the process of authentication, which consists in verifying the identity claimed by some system entity. There are several forms of identities widely-adopted today in the Internet, but they are based on some central entity. Project QualiChain aims to explore decentralised solutions based on blockchain technology, so in QualiChain we aim to use decentralised identities supported on one or more blockchains. This notion is being defined by the W3C under the designation of Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) [1]. 

The objective of the project is to design and implement an Identity and Access Control Management based on DIDs. We aim to support two Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) based on the OASIS standard eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML), which are current best practices in access control.

title: (PROJECT) Degree Coordination Decision Support System – data analytical component

title: [Dissertation] A Reference Implementation of Web Workers
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
JavaScript is the most widespread dynamic language. It is the de facto language for client-side web applications, used by more than 95% of websites [1]. Its behaviour, described in the ECMAScript English standard [2], is highly complex and full of corner cases. Furthermore, client-side JavaScript programs have access to an ever-growing number of browser APIs, making them extremely hard to analyse and debug.   

The Web Workers API [3] is a W3C API that allows client-side JavaScript programs to spawn background “workers”, which can be thought of as cooperative threads [4,5] that run in parallel with the program’s main page. Web Workers abide the non-preemptive multi-threading discipline as each worker runs to completion or until it voluntarily yields control. 

At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [11,12], a JavaScript compositional symbolic execution tool with support for verification [6], symbolic execution [7,13], and bi-abduction [8]. JaVerT has gathered interest from researchers both in academia and in industry. It has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [9], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [10]. 

Recently, JaVerT has been extended with a core events module that was used to implement DOM UI events and JavaScript promises. The **goal** of this project is to continue this line of work, using JaVerT’s core events module to implement the Web Workers API. The project will consist of the following three main tasks. Firstly, the student will extend JaVerT’s core events module to allow for message passing communication between workers. Then, the student will implement the Web Workers API directly in JavaScript, using JaVerT’s event primitives to interact with the core events module. Finally, the student will use the new version of JaVerT to symbolically analyse real world JavaScript projects that make use of Web Workers. 

[1] w3techs.com/technologies/details/cp-javascript
[2] ECMAScript Committee. The 10th Edition of the ECMAScript Language Specification. ECMA. 2019
[3] W3C Working Group. Web Workers. 2015. 
[4] M. Abadi et al. A Model of Cooperative Threads. POPL’09. 
[5] G. Boudol. Fair Cooperative Multithreading. ICCT’07. 
[6] J. Reynolds. Separation Logic: A Logic for Shared Mutable Data Structures. LICS’02.  
[7] P. Godefroid et al. DART: Directed Automated Random Testing. PLDI’05. 
[8] C. Calcagno et al. Compositional Shape Analysis by Means of Bi-abduction.  J. ACM. 2011.  
[9] https://research.fb.com/announcing-the-winners-of-the-facebook-continuous-reasoning-research-awards/
[10] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/encryption-sdk/latest/developer-guide/introduction.html
[11] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT: JavaScript Verification Toolchain. POPL’18. 
[12] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT 2.0: Compositional Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. POPL’19.  
[13] E. Torlak. A Lightweight Symbolic Virtual Machine for Solver Aided Host Languages. PLDI’14.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: Dissertação: Aplicação de técnicas de Machine Learning para desafiar Modelos de Risco de Crédito - EY
objectives:
Desenvolver e aplicar algoritmos de Machine Learning de forma a desafiar os modelos de risco de crédito tradicionais para estimar a probabilidade de um cliente bancário entrar em incumprimento. As tarefas associadas ao projeto incluem as atividades inerentes ao processo end-to­-end desde a obtenção de informação, tratamento e enriquecimento de variáveis, entre outras. O objetivo final é demonstrar como é que as técnicas de Machine Learning poderão ser aplicadas no âmbito do risco de crédito e apresentar os vários cenários e outputs das técnicas utilizadas.
Área/processo: A ser acordado e validado junto da entidade que disponibilizará os dados e na qual o trabalho será desenvolvido, mantendo, no entanto, a premissa de que deve estar circunscrito a um modelo de estimação da probabilidade de incumprimento.
Contexto: Atualmente, os bancos recorrem aos métodos tradicionais para estimar os fatores de risco de crédito passando pelas fases da definição e seleção dos dados e da metodologia, amostragens, análises univariadas e multivariadas, testes e seleção dos modelos. A aplicação de novas metodologias, como a aplicação de algoritmos de Machine Learning poderão tornar o processo de desenvolvimento de modelos mais eficiente e mais célere. No entanto, os modelos de Machine Learning são vistos muitas vezes como black boxes difíceis de explicar o que, na perspetiva dos reguladores, pode trazer alguns desafios.

Esta tese irá decorrer no contexto de colaboração com a empresa EY https://www.ey.com/pt/en/home
requirements: Disciplinas de sistemas de informação

title: Projeto: Unidrone LoRa, USV, ROV, IoT
location: ITI / LARSYS fieldwork to be conducted in Madeira with support form a research project
objectives: While popularity of drones may be seen in daily entertainment usage, USV and ROVs combined for aquatic expeditions remain at high cost or are tethered. This thesis will explore and implement the universal drone capable for both aerial and underwater surveys. Long range communication will be used for real-time telemetry, remote control and for assessing the marine biodiversity. Using the latest microcomputers and microcontrollers, drone will be capable to incorporate modular sensors (e.g. camera, hydrophone, temp, salinity, pH), communicating the data from remote distances. Additional attention will be made to understand the location of the drone below water. Intended activities will be performed in close collaboration with marine biologists from Observatorio Oceanografico and ITI LARSyS.
requirements: Microcontroller development (e.g. Arduino, pyCOM). This project will require some basic knowledge of electronics and sensor interface and integration

title: Dissertação || MEDIA: MEDical Integration Architecture
observations:
Mais informação:  https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado 

Proposto por aluna: Ana Sofia Godinho …………………………  Nº Aluno:… 94005 …
objectives:
Motivation: 

As growing costs pressure health systems, mainly due to an ageing population, the rise of the private medical service providers has been growing in Portugal.  In 2013, nearly half of Portugal’s hospitals were private. Over the last ten years, private hospitals have grown in consultations, number of beds, emergency rooms and diagnostic tests. The number of outpatient medical consultations increased steadily between 2002 and 2013, from 9,8 million to 17,6 million visits, with private hospitals accounting for 5,1 million consultations, 29% of the total. 
The growth of private health insurance, reduced waiting times and advanced technology, are among the main growth drivers for private medical service providers.
Although major private medical service providers in Portugal have an electronic reservation system, the process of booking a medical consultation is generally a tedious process and always limited to the service provider’s ecosystem. 
MedClick provides a one-stop platform to book a medical appointment in a fast and user friendly way, across multiple medical service providers. Whether on a PC, tablet or smartphone, patients will be able to conveniently browse all available booking options, based on date, location, price, insurance providers, or customer reviews and recommendations. 


Description:
MedClick is an online platform that is being implemented and is expected to be available online through a web portal and mobile apps for Android and iOS smartphones. The major functionalities are described bellow: 

 
The platform provides a common ground for several types of users: the patients, the doctors, the administrator, the contact center staff, the sales team personnel, and the insurance company
 
Patients will be able to access the portal and immediately search for a doctor and book a medical appointment. 
In order to fulfill Medclick goals the integration among the different players is central, including the integration among healthcare providers (Clinics, hospitals), healthcare professionals (medical doctors, nurses), patients, insurances, etc..
This integration must be defined at a business, information, application and technological levels, under a Service Oriented Architecture, ensuring the levels of adaptability and rigor in the face of change that can be anticipated, leaving open Changes and improvements that may prove necessary.
This thesis is expected to define the “MedClick connector” architecture, creating an Enterprise integration roadmap for medclick, including:
•	Business Process integration architecture
•	Information integration architecture
•	Service integration architecture
•	Technological integration architecture

After the definition of the Enterprise integration strategy and architecture, an Enterprise Service Bus prototype for MedClick integration is expected to be configured, ensuring the integration with different parties; In this prototype the appointment scheduling business process is supposed to be configure along with the information entities, services and IT services needed.
requirements:
Expected results: 1 MedClick Integration Architecture specification
2. MedClick prototype implementation
3. Paper Publication.

title: Dissertation: Prioritizingg Facebook's Infer Static Analysis Tool Warnings
objectives:
Infer is a static analysis tool developed and used at Facebook to detect bugs in Java and C/C++/Objective-C code before it ships [1]. If you give Infer some code, it produces a list of potential bugs. Anyone can use Infer to intercept critical bugs before they have shipped to users, and help prevent crashes or poor performance.

The goal of this project is to explore the foundations and applications of Infer, and prioritise the set of warnings in order to ease adoption and reduce false positives/negatives.

You will be working on a project that can have real-world impact. Envisaged areas of application include security and energy-aware software, but this will be defined considering the student's interests.

[1] https://fbinfer.com
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (50%)
title: Dissertação: Security testing using a dynamic analysis approach
objectives:
A large class of vulnerabilities in web applications originates in programs that enable user input information to affect the values of certain parameters of security sensitive functions. In other words, these programs encode an illegal information flow, in the sense that low integrity -- tainted -- information (user input) may interfere with high integrity parameters of sensitive functions (so called sensitive sinks). This means that users are given the power to alter the behavior of sensitive functions, and in the worst case may be able to induce the program to perform security violations.

Often, such illegal information flows are desirable as, for instance, it is useful to be able to use the inputted data for building SQL queries, so we do not want to reject them entirely. It is thus necessary to differentiate illegal flows that can be exploited, where a vulnerability exists, from those that are inoffensive and can be deemed secure, or endorsed, where there is no vulnerability. One approach is to only accept programs that properly validate the user input, and by so restrict the power of the user to acceptable limits, in effect neutralizing the potential vulnerability.

The aim of this thesis is to study how vulnerabilities in code written in different server-side languages (e.g., PHP and JavaScript) can be detected dynamically by means of dynamic taint analysis. The objective is to implement a dynamic analysis tool to detect common attacks against code running in a web server. Specifically, the tool has to verify if unsanitized/unvalidated input reaches certain sensitive sinks (or sensitive functions), without passing through validation/sanitization functions.
requirements:
The first step will be to design the tool for doing that on PHP code. The tool works in two steps:- extract a trace of the code executed using a debugging framework;
- analyse that trace.

The tool essentially has to search for certain vulnerable patterns in the traces. All patterns have 4 elements:
: • name of vulnerability (e.g., SQL injection)
	• a set of entry points (e.g., $_GET, $_POST),
	• a set of sanitization/validation functions (e.g., mysql_real_escape_string),
	• and a set of sensitive sinks (e.g., mysql_query). 

If a data flow comes from an entry point and reaches a sensitive sink:
	• if it passes through a sanitization/validation function, there is probably no vulnerability;
	• if it does not pass through a sanitization/validation function, there is probably a vulnerability.

The tool has to look for these patterns in the traces. The patterns are loaded from a configuration file.

The second part of the project involves generalizing that tool for other languages. This part will be based on the notion of micro-grammars [B+16]. The idea is to check the traces using incomplete language grammars (“micro-grammars”) that describe only relevant portions of a language. Therefore, there will be a micro-grammar for PHP and another, slightly different, for a second language.

References:
[B+16] Brown et al. "How to Build Static Checking Systems Using Orders of Magnitude Less Code”. In ASPLOS 2016
[M+16] Medeiros et al. "Detecting and Removing Web Application Vulnerabilities with Static Analysis and Data Mining". IEEE Transactions on Reliability, 65(1):54-69, 2016.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Enabling a persistent ground/aerial robot mission through cooperative task planning
location: ISR/IST’s Intelligent Robots and Systems group (http://welcome.isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/labs/irsgroup/) - Torre Norte, and outdoor spaces at IST and elsewhere (e.g., hotspots of the Lisbon Robotics Cluster - see http://www.lisboarobotics.com/pt/).
objectives:
At the Intelligent Robots and Systems Group (IRSg) we are working on the idea of employing a team of ground and aerial robots to perform surveillance and inspection of renewable energy plants such as large solar farms. 
In this project the student is expected to investigate and address the problem of cooperative task planning for performing persistent swarm missions (I.e. missions that are much longer than the battery life of individual robots). For example, for continues monitoring of solar farms, how can the aerial robots replace each other to always maintain a fixed number of robots over the target area while allowing old robots to go and recharge by landing on the ground robots.
 For this purpose, the students need to study existing mission planning techniques and propose a distributed planning strategy for the intended application while considering the constraints of both aerial and ground robots. For example, constraints such as the limited energy of the aerial robots, the limited movement and traveling speed of ground robots, the location and time requirements of individual tasks, the limited communication range between the robots and the different robot capabilities are some of the things to be considered for an efficient planning.
requirements: Good background in robot task planning and control is required. Knowledge of computer programming and ROS is required.

title: Projecto: Side-channel setup for chip testing
objectives:
In current embed systems cryptography is a fundamental component in the so called smart devices, e.g. citizen card or PayTV systems. The resistance of these devices towards side-channel attacks (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Side-channel_attack) needs to be tested in order to determine there reliability. One of the most common side channel attacks classes currently in used is the Differential Power Attacks (DPA) and Differential Electro-magnetic Attacks (DEMA) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_power_analysis). 

These testes imply the realization of the attack it self, either by simulation or in the device itself. In order for these testes to be performed in the devices a measuring apparatus needs to be use in order to measure the consumed power and emanated electromagnetic radiation.

The goal of this thesis is to develop the measuring apparatus needed to perform these side-channel analysis attacks. In order to make these attacks more efficient it is required to identify where in the tested chip the cryptographic units are located. This can be accomplished with the identification of the processing “hot-spots” according to the execution flow. The temporal mapping of this processing “hot-spots” is to be performed by detecting the intensity of the electro-magnetic radiation during the execution period.
This platform is also to be integrated into the side-channel attack platform where real attacks are to be performed over security chips, e.g. smart cards or PayTV systems. The improvement of these attacks will be used to demonstrate the usability of the developed platform.
requirements: Interest in the development of embedded systems

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: Parallel Algorithm for Multi-Objective Combinatorial Optimization
observations: A scholarship might be available for the second semester.
objectives:
There are many formulations such as Pseudo-Boolean Optimization, Integer Linear
Programming, etc. where the goal is to find an assignment to the problem
variables such that a set of constraints must be satisfied while the value
of an objective function is optimized.

However, in several real-world problems, there is more than one criteria
to be optimized. In this thesis proposal, the goal is to develop a new
parallel algorithm for Multi-Objective Combinatorial Optimization
where the intial problem instance is first split into many smaller
problems where effective algorithms are to be used in parallel.

title: Dissertation: Multi-party Affective Expression for Synthetic Characters
objectives:
In digital games featuring non-player characters (NPC), an important component of the gaming experience is related to how the game coherently communicates certain emotions to the player through the NPC's animations. When multiple NPC's are concurrently displaying non-verbal behaviour through their animations, however, these animations generally interfere with each other and hinder the clear communication of affect. This work explores how synchronicity and interruptions could be used to enhance the communication of certain emotions to the player.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico.

supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
title: [Dissertação] From Movement to Sound and Music, a Computational Creativity approach
observations:
This Thesis is for student 83451 Edgar Carita Miguéns Santos Meireles.
The Project will involve meetings with musicians and musicologists (experts on the domain).
objectives:
Sound and Music Generation is an interesting topic of Computational Creativity and Musicology and in this Thesis we aim at continuing with the creation of sound and music from sequences of images.
Current work (Proposal 11000 [Dissertação] Sound and Music Generation from a Video Sequence) involves the detection of objects and their edges, optical flow, and their movement tracking and convert them into sound that is aligned with those changes and can constitute a soundtrack for that video sequence. 

In the context of this Thesis, we aim at further elaborating on the Sound and Music Generation idea under development by using the changes in a sequence of images of dancers to generate sound and music that is aligned with the movements of the dancer, in this case the soundtrack of the performance. It involves filming performances of dancers and from these create a mapping from the language of these movements into a sequence of notes, such that both movements and music are properly aligned.
requirements: This Thesis is for student 83451 Edgar Carita Miguéns Santos Meireles.The Project will involve meetings with musicians and musicologists (experts on the domain).

title: Dissertação || Distributed, Trustless, Service Providing with a Network of Blockchains
observations: Trabalho realizado em conjunto com Eng.Rafael Belchior e Prof. Miguel Pupo Correia
objectives:
Motivation: Given the end of the hype cycle of the Blockchain technology, the technology is now maturing. Blockchain is useful when there are several untrusting parties that need to share data and/or perform computations. When entities need to cooperate, Smart contracts that encompass the business logic can be written and deployed on a blockchain, public or private (e.g. Ethereum or Hyperledger Fabric). Nonetheless, such smart contracts, and cooperative environment suffer from two problems: 1) they are tied to a specific blockchain implementation, 2) services they provide rely on the survivability of a particular blockchain.
The main idea of this master thesis is to leverage a set of blockchains to increase dependability of blockchain powered services, administrated by several stakeholders.  

Description: Currently, there are several options that allow developers to build and interoperable custom blockchains. Popular implementations are Cosmos and Polkadot. Cosmos is a network of many independent blockchains, called zones. Zones are powered by the Tendermint Core. Tendermint Core is an application-agnostic “consensus engine” that can turn any deterministic blackbox application into a distributedly replicated blockchain. Tendermint Core connects to blockchain applications via the Application Blockchain Interface (ABCI). Thus, ABCI allows for blockchain applications to be programmed in any language, not just the programming language that the consensus engine is written in.Zones can also serve as blockchain-backed versions of enterprise systems, where pieces of a particular service that are traditionally run by an organization or group of organizations are instead run as a ABCI application on a certain zone, which allows it to inherit the security and interoperability of the public Cosmos network without sacrificing control over the underlying service. Polkadot allows cross-blockchain transfer of data and assets. In Polkadot, developers can develop side chains - parachains, which implement a custom blockchain-which can be connected to other blockchains. This makes it possible to build applications that get permissioned data from a private blockchain and use it on a public blockchain. For instance, a school's private, permissioned academic records chain could send a proof to a degree-verification smart contract on a public chain.
requirements:
Expected results: 1. Framework for creating, deploying and maintaining services with several blockchains/parachains 
2. Proof of concept implementation with the Cosmos Network or Polkadot
3.  Paper Publication

title: [Dissertação] Evolução e auto-organização da cooperação
observations:
Para mais informações p.f. contactar os orientadores desta proposta de tese:

Francisco C. Santos (INESC-ID & DEI/IST, Universidade de Lisboa)
email: franciscocsantos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
web: http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/franciscocsantos/
objectives:
A formalização dos mecanismos que explicam e fomentam a evolução da cooperação continua a constituir um enorme desafio. Por ser aparentemente paradoxal e contrária ao princípio da racionalidade (que prevê a maximização dos ganhos individuais), a cooperação continua a ser um fenómeno de enorme interesse científico partilhado por variadíssimas áreas do saber, das duras às ciências biológicas e às sociais. 

Usando princípios de teoria de jogos, dinâmicas evolutivas e simulação de sistemas complexos, esta proposta sugere investigar mecanismos que expliquem como sociedades de indivíduos se auto-organizam, conseguindo dessa forma resolver conflitos sociais através da cooperação. Em particular, a tese deverá focar aspectos relacionados com mecanismos de reciprocidade e/ou investigação de comportamentos cooperativos em redes complexas.  Os modelos a desenvolver focarão a análise processos dinâmicos co-evolutivos. 

No final desta tese é esperado que o/a candidato/a seja capaz de:
i) recorrer às ferramentas de teoria de jogos e dinâmicas de populações para descrever processos evolutivos de auto-organização.
ii) criar e analisar modelos que possibilitem compreender e isolar efeitos de alguns mecanismos de auto-organização responsáveis pela evolução da cooperação observada na natureza.

Resultado esperado: 
Desenvolvimento e análise de resultados de um (ou mais) modelos teóricos. Divulgação dos resultados obtidos.
requirements: A natureza do projecto requer um gosto particular por parte do candidato por áreas de investigação interdisciplinar, permitindo também que alunos das mais diversas áreas de formação se possam candidatar.

title: Dissertation: Automated Synthesis of Real-World Programs
objectives:
Software synthesis has recently seen many developments that promise to change the way software is developed in specific domains. Suslik [1] is a recent research tool capable of automatically synthesising programs from logic specifications. This project is about extending Suslik to support richer specifications, thus enabling synthesis of more interesting programs. Potential extensions include support for information flow properties and for concurrent programs. It is suggested to explore Suslik to synthesise components of a real-world system (e.g. components of a microkernel such as FreeRTOS).

[1] https://github.com/TyGuS/suslik
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (50%)
title: Dissertation: Machine learning for Breast screening diagnosis
objectives:
Breast cancer is amongst the most diagnosed cancers affecting women worldwide. One of the most effective ways of increasing the survival rate for this
disease is based on early detection. Screening programs aim to provide such early detection by diagnosing at-risk, asymptomatic patients, allowing for an early intervention and treatment. 

Machine learning has played a fundamental role to automate methods, such as the one mentioned above. The goal of this thesis is to automatically classify the lesion severity through the use of the BIRADS. To accomplish this a DenseNet or ResNet will be used to match the above requirement. Several stages characterize this work. First, the performance accuracy of the Net will be teste using a single modality (i.e. Mamography that is the first modality to be inspected in the radiologist's diagnosis). A second stage will comprise the use of more than one image modality (i.e. Mammography and Echography). An experimental evaluation will be conducted to see if there is advantages of using a multi-modal setup. Also, a study comprising the architecture as well as the loss function (e.g. cross-entropy, squared error) will be studied to ascertain the impact of the two scenarios mentioned above (single vs. multi.modality).
requirements:
Conhecimento de  programação em:
- TensorFlow
- Pytorch

supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (50%)
specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Business processes compliance for controlling run-time operation using Atlas
observations:
Referências a trabalho prévio:
Marques, R., Guerreiro, S. (2016). Mecanismo de controlo para a frente orientado ao risco como garantia da conformidade da execução de processos de negócio, accepted for Revista Ibérica de Sistemas e Tecnologias de Informação (RISTI), 20, pp. 34{47, DOI: 10.17013/risti.20.34-47, ISSN: 1646- 9895, https://goo.gl/vn3Uy0. Q3 SCImago.
objectives:
An organization encompasses a network of people and machines working, and communicating, in an integrated way that produces large amounts of data. The organizational activity could be divided in three intervals in time: the ex-ante - what happens before execution, the ex-dure - during execution and the ex-post - after executing events.
Ex-ante includes the modeling skills, e.g., business processes modeling, To-Be Enterprise Architecture (EA) models definition. Disparate specification languages are usually used: Archimate, BPMN, UML, SysML, etc. Ex-dure includes the ability to support the operation directly from the ex-ante models definition, e.g., ontological execution machines. In general terms, this ability is related with Model-Driven Development (MDD). Ex-post includes the decision making processes to estimate future behavior from the available data from the past executions, e.g., Decision trees, Process mining, Data mining, etc.
 
The integration of these three intervals in time offer a full description of the organizational behavior control: what we want to execute, the support for the operational environment founded directly by the model definitions, and a final analysis and action about (non)compliance situations. Organizational control is understood as the set of artifacts that are able to prescribe, observe and act in the reality, which impacts the behavior of the organization and that is able to change its shape and its performance. This definition, and the supporting theoretical concepts, is broad enough to be applicable to various real-time applications.
 
One specific organizational control application that has been researched extensively, both in the engineering and management area, is the business processes compliance [10]. It encompasses the ability to check whether ex-ante business processes models are followed in ex-dure by its instances, and then act with a change or an enhancement in ex-post. Where a business process is performed by actors, aims at producing a new service or product, demands an event-based behavior modeling that orchestrate the communication between actors, and uses resources, e.g., information, time, etc.   
 
However, most of the business processes compliance solutions consider that ex-dure is fully known. In reality, due to many design and operational reasons, organizations have an incomplete understanding of ex-dure, and nevertheless, organizational ex-post decisions based on partial information must be taken. This problem is recognized with high impact in the industries of healthcare, financial, public administration, etc. 
Therefore, the goal of this project is to solve the problem of how to design, implement and manage business processes compliance solutions that are operating in partially observable environments.

Resultados Esperados: 
1. Levantamento de Estado da Arte
2. Proposta de modelo conceptual que integre os modelos de representação de processos de negócio e os mecanismos de compliance (incluindo a observação parcial, a solução para a decisão e a tomada de acções de controlo).
3. Avaliação do modelo conceptual, usando design science research (DSR).  
4. Publicação de artigo
requirements: Disciplinas de sistemas de informação

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: Detecting malware with code2vec
observations:
Alon et al. (2019) Uri Alon, Meital Zilberstein, Omer Levy, and Eran Yahav, 2019 Proceedings of the ACM on Programming Languages archive. 3 (40)

https://code2vec.org/
objectives:
As there is growing importance for using machine learning model to analyze and predict software code. Alon et al. (2019) presented neural model for representing snippet of code as continuous distributed vectors while demonstrated the utility of their approach by utilizing it to execute prediction of a method ́s name from the vector representation of its body. Alon et al. (2019) trained their model with more than 12 million methods in order to make it predict methods name of a new code effectively.

In the research paper, Alon et al. (2019) discussed two interesting machine-learning based applications for the code2vec algorithm, which are: automatic code review and retrieval API discovery. Yet, a more promising application is to detect malware. That is, the goal of this thesis is to training the code2vec neural network
on many pieces of code that already contains malware, and the use the neural network to do the task of predicting if new piece of code has malware or not.
requirements:
Good Commandment of EnglishInterest or Good Commandment Deep Learning Technologies
Interest for Software Engineering

objectives:
Infer is a static analysis tool developed and used at Facebook to detect bugs in Java and C/C++/Objective-C code before it ships [1]. If you give Infer some code, it produces a list of potential bugs. Anyone can use Infer to intercept critical bugs before they have shipped to users, and help prevent crashes or poor performance.

The goal of this project is to explore the foundations and applications of Infer, by implementing new static analyses that can be used to detect bugs in real-world code.

title: Dissertation: FastGeo - Visualizing large amounts of georeferenced data
observations:
BigData meets Dados Geográficos! É fácil registar, com um simples telemóvel onde estivemos. Já conseguimos registar e limpar os dados. Mas… mostrar uma track é fácil. Mostrar 1000 nem tanto… E se forem todos os autocarros da Carris durante um ano?

Usando infovis, como produzir visualizações que mostram, de forma eficaz e eficiente, grandes quantidades de dados geo-referenciados? Se calhar desenhar cada ponto/linha individualmente não funciona. Para dados pontuais, soluções comuns são os heatmaps e o binning. Perde-se, no entanto, a ideia dos eventos isolados! Para desenhar rotas, tracks, não há uma boa solução. Mais: não importa apenas mostrar onde se andou, mas também quando. Aspetos como regularidade, frequência e recência são relevantes também. Como apresentar séries temporais? Como comparar os caminhos feitos pelos táxi de Lisboa em 2010 e em 2019 (malditos turistas!)?
objectives: Estudar a melhor forma de visualizar grandes quantidades de dados geo-referenciados, mantendo a compreensão da sua distribuição não só espacial mas temporal (“segui este caminho antigamente, mas agora tenho vindo por aquele”). Foco em eventos, e streaming data!
requirements: Frequência da UC de Visualização de Informação

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: (Dissertation) Gestão de dados científicos para BioData.pt
observations: Integração em projecto nacional com várias entidades e desenvolvido em contexto internacional
objectives:
BioData.pt é uma infraestrutura científica nacional de gestão e processamento de dados científicos no domínio da Biologia (em especial, mas não só, de dados genómicos de plantas): https://biodata.pt/
A BioData.pt está integrada na rede Europeia Elixir: https://elixir-europe.org/
O objectivo deste projecto é o desenvolvimento de serviços para a BioData.pt, em estreita colaboração com as outras infraestruturas da rede Elixir, segundo princípio da RDA: https://www.rd-alliance.org/ (em especial os princípio FAIR: https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/) e outras referências internacionais (e.g. https://libraries.mit.edu/data-management/)
requirements: Interesse por temas de "big data" e soluções "open-source" para sistemas de relativa complexidade (dependendo do interesse e capacidade do aluno, o projecto pode envolver ou não desafios mais tecnológicos, como por exemplo a gestão de docking/virtualização de máquinas, ou mais conceptuais, como por exemplo o desenvolvimento de planos de gestão de dados com base em tecnologia semântica (ontologias e esquemas flexíveis).Facilidade de comunicação em língua Inglesa

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: [Project] MySteps: An Integrated LifeLogging Tool for Geo-Referenced Data
observations:
É fácil registar, com um simples telemóvel onde estivemos. Já conseguimos registar e limpar os dados. Mas… mostrar uma track é fácil. Mostrar 1000 nem tanto… E se forem todos os autocarros da Carris durante um ano?

Ao longo dos anos, vários trabalhos têm abordado este problema. O GatherMySteps tratou da recolha das tracks.  FollowMySteps permitia ver em mobile, on the go. O Where Have I Been permite fazer queries visuais sobre os dados. O BigGeo permite visualizá-los. Mas, cada um destes trabalhos, todos web-based, é independente dos demais! Não faz sentido. Por isso, queremos produzir uma aplicação consistente e coerente englobando todas estas vertentes. Isto passará por integrar as aplicações tanto a nível de interface como backend, re-aproveitando boa parte do que existe. Em alguns aspetos será mais simples do que parece: por exemplo, o modelo de dados não é dissimilar. Com base neste trabalho, será produzida uma plataforma para que novos trabalhos possam ir mais além, se re-inventar a roda. On the shoulders of Giants!
objectives: Integrar os vários trabalhos já realizados nesta área num todo coerente, que sirva como base a desenvolvimentos futuros.

title: Dissertação: Temporal sequence alignment for clustering longitudinal clinical data
observations: The work will be supported by a strong collaboration network between INESC-ID, IT and also IMM/Fac. Medicina.
objectives:
Patient stratification is a key task in clinical decision since it can support physicians to choose treatments in a personalized way. Given the increasing availability of electronical medical records (EMR) with longitudinal data, one crucial problem is how to cluster efficiently the patients based on temporal information obtained in medical appointments.
The goal of this dissertation is to develop clustering methods for temporal data, in particular using sequence alignment scores.
The work comprises the following steps:
1. Study state-of-the-art clustering methods for longitudinal data.
2. Develop robust and efficient methods for choosing the number of clusters and evaluate them individually.
3. Implement the methods and integrate them with existing tools.
4. Test on simulated and real clinical data, providing an interpretation of the results.
5. Write the thesis.
requirements: Interest in machine learning, bioinformatics and computational biology, as well as good implementation skills. It is preferred, although not mandatory, that students are knowledgeable about algorithms and data structures, object oriented programming, artificial intelligence and optimization. Students with good marks in courses related with the thesis topics will be preferred. Minimum average mark required: 15 (Bachelor)

title: Dissertação: Study of the brain’s dynamic functional connectivity with simultaneous EEG-fMRI: a network science approach
observations: Francisca Ayres Basto Soares Ribeiro has already manifested interest in this thesis.
objectives:
Large-scale brain networks of functionally connected brain regions have been extensively studied using functional MRI (fMRI), particularly based on the observation of spontaneous fluctuations of the fMRI signal temporally-correlated across the brain during rest. The rapidly growing field of brain connectomics has already shown great potential to provide novel insights into brain function as well as biomarkers of various neurological and psychiatric diseases. Critically, it has recently been recognized that the brain's functional connectivity (FC) is not stationary, but in fact displays spontaneous variations on short time scales of seconds to minutes [review by Preti et al., NeuroImage 160 (2017) 41–54]. It has been shown that dynamic FC (dFC) correlates with brain state (stimulation/task, eye closure, vigilance, arousal/sleep/anaesthesia, drug manipulation, age, gender, disease), and it can predict it better than static FC [review by Thompson et al., Neuroimage Neuroimage 180 (2018), 448-462]. However, the significance of dFC remains a matter of debate.

Graph theory and network analysis have been shown to offer promising insights on the dynamics of network integration and segregation. On the other hand, the simultaneous acquisition of the electroencephalogram (EEG) with fMRI provides the possibility of assessing the electrophysiological underpinning of such network dynamics. However, only one study has so far attempted to relate dFC graph-theory properties with EEG [Tagliazucchi et al., Front. Hum.  Neurosci. (2012)].

In this Project, we aim to investigate graph-theory properties of dFC and their EEG correlates by employing state-of-the-art network science methodologies. Simultaneous EEG-fMRI datasets collected from healthy subjects as well as epilepsy patients will be used. The EEG and fMRI data have been previously pre-processed, and analysed by a neurophysiologist (in the case of epilepsy) [as in Abreu et al., Nature: Scientific Reports, 9 (2019), 638]. Firstly, network analysis techniques will be employed taking into account the time-varying nature of underlying networks, and suitable graph features will be extracted from the fMRI dFC data. The relationship between these features and the simultaneous EEG recordings will be investigated. Secondly, multi-layer networks will be considered in order to incorporate and analyse the fMRI data as well as the EEG data simultaneously, by applying multi-layer network mining techniques.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: DISSERTAÇÃO: An Automated Debugging plugin for Visual Studio Code
observations: Exceptional candidates may be offered a scholarship.
objectives:
GZoltar is a tool set for automatic fault localization (aka automatic debugging). Currently, it is available as a plugin for the Eclipse IDE. In the last couple of years, others IDEs have surpassed Eclipse in terms of popularity (e.g., IntelliJ and Visual Studio Code). 

Visual Studio Code, Code for short, is a source-code editor developed by Microsoft for Windows, Linux and macOS. It is highly customizable, allowing users to change the theme, keyboard shortcuts, preferences, and install extensions that add additional functionality. The source code is free and open source and released under the permissive MIT License. 

The main objective of this thesis is to develop a plugin offering the GZoltar functionalities (see www.gzoltar.com). 

As we develop GZoltar further, we will also seek to contribute the with the following:  
- Extend the GZoltar's Java fault localization tools to instrument other JVM languages such as Clojure, Scala and Kotlin (other languages could also be considered);
- Develop GZoltar's frontends that support popular build systems (e.g.: sbt, gradle, leiningen, bazel) and testing frameworks;
- Evaluate the effectiveness of spectrum-based fault localization reports across the different languages, build systems and testing frameworks in the JVM ecosystem.
requirements: - Experience with git and Java development- JVM languages & Java Bytecode programming experience is recommended

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: Unsat-based algorithm for Multi-Objective Combinatorial Optimization
objectives:
Unsat-based algorithms are well-known to outperform classic approaches for several classes of problems in Maximum Satisfiability. 
However, these algorithms are yet to be explored in the context of Multi-Objective optimization.
In this work, several unsat-based approaches are to be tested for solving formulations of MOCO such as Virtual Machine Consolidation,
Software Product Lines Configuration, among other.

title: (DISSERTATION) Optimization of Data Cleaning Programs
observations: O aluno Tiago Luiz, MEIC-T, demonstrou interesse nesta tese.
objectives:
Data cleaning is recognized as a central feature of data analysis and management tools. Data cleaning aims at converting source data into target data without errors, missing values, duplicates and inconsistencies. A data cleaning program is typically modeled as: (i) a graph of data transformations or through (ii) a set of data quality rules [1]. In (i), data transformations are implemented by data cleaning operators whose execution clean data. In (ii), data quality rules express conditions that data must satisfy to be considered of good quality or else a violation occurs and a data repair that corrects the data must be found. Data repairs are typically selected from the set of possible data repairs using heuristics.
None of these two approaches was primarily developed to handle large amounts of data coming from heterogeneous sources, i.e., forming the so-called Big Data [2]. Only recently, works were proposed to deal with data cleaning for Big Data. Nevertheless, they only focus on specific data cleaning tasks. The authors of [3], [4], [5] and [6] focus on data deduplication for Big Data sets by leveraging state-of-the-art techniques for deduplication into the MapReduce paradigm [7]. BigDansing [8], a data cleaning framework for Big Data based on the NADEEF framework [9], offers a formalism to specify quality rules in a distributed environment. Recently, [10] proposed an approach to optimize data cleaning programs based on a declarative approach.

Objectives: The goal of this work is to build a first version of a data cleaning optimizer to integrate in a data cleaning prototype called Cleenex [11]. This optimizer will include a cost model that is able to find the best executable data cleaning flow graph, i.e., the one that leads to an efficient data cleaning process. This cost model will take into account that a logical data cleaning operator can be executed by different algorithms and some of these algorithms are executed in a distributed environment.

Results expected: A first prototype of the CLENNEX optimizer and a published paper describing the optimizer and preliminary experiments.
requirements:
Students must have:• finished their 3-year degree on Information Systems and Computer Engineering (LEIC) with an average grade >= 14/20 for IST students
• completed with success (grade >= 16/20) the following Master’s course: Analysis and Data Integration and obtained a grade >= 16 in the following 3-year degree courses: Databases, Object-Oriented Programming, Software Engineering, Human-Computer Interaction
• an average grade of the master’s courses so far >= 16/20.
• Students must be working full-time on their Master thesis therefore people who are working in a company on a completely different
subject will not be accepted.

title: Dissertation: Automatic Detection of Security Vulnerabilities in Java Code
objectives:
Static analysis tools are becoming increasingly adopted by industry, as they can be used to detect bugs in source code before the code ships.

The goal of this project is to explore static analysis tools and techniques for detection of security issues in real-world Java code. Specific areas of application will be defined together with the student, considering the student's interests. For example, a suggestion is to create a prototype capable of detecting side-channel vulnerabilities (and, in more general, so-called k-safety properties).
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: Dissertaçao: Fault-Tolerant on-Board Image Processor
observations:
Esta tese insere-se num projecto de investigação em execução no Inesc-id:
https://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/ist14551/projs/sarrroca/
Contactos: Prof. Horácio Neto,
Prof. Rui Duarte , INESC-ID, sala 309, ext. 251
objectives:
O objetivo desta tese é o desenvolvimento, através da programação em C/C++, de um acelerador tolerante a falhas para geração de imagens de satélite, a partir dos sinais recolhidos "on-board" e explorando o paralelismo oferecido pela tecnologia reconfigurável (FPGAs).
O processamento dos sinais adquiridos pelo satélite tem um custo computacional elevado, pelo que reduzir o tempo de processamento necessário é um desafio importante e actual. Adicionalmente, o espaço é um ambiente hostil para os circuitos electrónicos, e como tal é necessário dotar os sistemas de capacidade para tolerar e recuperar de falhas.
O projecto a realizar tem como alvo um sistema que combina CPU dual-core com tecnologia reconfigurável, onde parte do algortimo executa em software e a outra parte em hardware (e.g. Xilinx Zynq).
requirements: Dá-se preferência a quem tenha média de curso superior a 14 valores e queira fazer a disciplina de IPEEC.

title: Projeto: BioSPPy Web Application - Aplicação para sinais neurofisiológicos
objectives:
O BioSPPy é um conjunto de ferramentas para processamento de sinais neurofisiológicos, tudo escrito em Python. Os sinais neurofisiológicos que usamos são principalmente as ondas cerebrais, o batimento cardíaco e a resposta galvânica da pele. Há inúmeras aplicações para a utilização destes bio-sinais, associadas ao que se chama de Brain-Computer Interfaces.
Esta toolbox junta diferentes métodos de processamento de sinais e métodos de reconhecimento de padrões de forma a permitir a análise de bio-sinais, ou seja, desses mesmos sinais neurofisiológicos.
O objetivo deste Projeto é desenvolver uma aplicação web para a biblioteca Python BioSPPy.
requirements: Conhecimentos de programação em Python (não essenciais mas preferíveis).

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: [Project] DynaGame: Gamifying IST Courses
observations:
Desde há alguns anos temos ensinado a disciplina de PCM de modo diferente: é um jogo! Mas este uso da gamificação tem com um custo adicional: muitas coisas para fazermos manualmente incluindo correr os scripts, o que leva a assíncronias, e um que outro bug. Em particular, a atribuição de badges, XP, etc. é feita por um script, hard-coded, o que limita a expressividade do jogo.

Já há algum trabalho feito para o desenvolvimento de um sistema de regras, mas falta terminar, e integrar com o resto do sistema, para que partilhe vocabulário, seja possível escrever regras para os módulos de jogo activos, etc.
objectives: O objetivo aqui é ajudar a criar um sistema de regras configurável para a gestão e atribuição dos XP, etc. que permita melhores tempos de resposta e a configuração do jogo de modo mais flexível e eficaz. Em particular, este deve ser integrado com o sistema já existente para produzir um todo coeso.

title: [Dissertation] Fraud Detection in Complex Networks
observations:
- Motivation -
Many behaviors in society can be modelled as a complex network. For instance, social relations, logistic networks, exchange of information, or economic relations. A common example is that of public contracts where collusion between bidders might increase the prices.

- Goals -
The goal of this thesis is to understand the complex behaviors in a society, model them and use such models to detect relations between different entities. These analyses will be used to detect fraud or collusions between different entities.


- References -

1.: Luo, B., & Hancock, E. R. (2001). Structural graph matching using the EM algorithm and singular value decomposition. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence, 23(10), 1120-1136.
2.	Wang, T., Ling, H., Lang, C., & Feng, S. (2017). Graph Matching with Adaptive and Branching Path Following. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence.
3.	Foggia, P., Percannella, G., & Vento, M. (2014). Graph matching and learning in pattern recognition in the last 10 years. International Journal of Pattern Recognition and Artificial Intelligence, 28(01), 1450001.
4.	Jiang, B., Tang, J., Ding, C., Gong, Y., & Luo, B. (2017). Graph Matching via Multiplicative Update Algorithm. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (pp. 3190-3198).
5.	Akoglu, L., Tong, H., & Koutra, D. (2015). Graph based anomaly detection and description: a survey. Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery, 29(3), 626-688.
6.	Manzoor, E., Milajerdi, S. M., & Akoglu, L. (2016, August). Fast memory-efficient anomaly detection in streaming heterogeneous graphs. In Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGKDD International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (pp. 1035-1044). ACM.
requirements: The student needs to have very good programming skills, knowledge of machine learning methods, and interest in novel machine learning approaches.
