specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Project: DynaSlides
observations:
Slides… haverá aulas que não usam slides? Mas são estáticos! Ou se faz um vídeo à parte, ou é preciso mudar de janela para fazer a demo… MOSTRAR como funciona seria melhor do que apenas EXPLICAR como funciona…

Tivémos uma aula sobre JPEG. Mostrei várias matrizes, em slides separados… E se tivéssemos visto a coisa a mudar e calcular mesmo? E se a aula com as curvas de Bezier tivessem lá curvas com os control points que pudesse manipular para explicar? E se na disciplina de VI pudesse ter as demos integradas na apresentação, ou mesmo fazer exemplos on the fly? O reveal.js já dá alguma versatilidade para criar apresentações HTML-based, mas é muito “anti-zen”, e está pensado para coisas estáticas. E a autoria é muito low level… Mas… é HTML! The sky is the limit! Salvem os vossos colegas do ano seguinte de uma vida de slides aborrecidos!
objectives: Extender a framework reveal.js (HTML-based slide presentations) para permitir slides interativos e dinâmicos, numa lógica “presentation zen”, usando conceitos de interfaces reactivas e notebooks (eg: https://jupyter.org/, https://observablehq.com).
requirements: Bons conhecimentos de tecnologia web (frontend e backend)

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Applications of Data and Software Science to Biogeography -- Climate change and Biodiversity
observations:
More information:  http://web.ist.utl.pt/~ist24690/thesisproposals/

Ana Matos - ana.matos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
Francisco C. Santos - franciscocsantos@ist.utl.pt
Miguel Araujo - maraujo@mncn.csic.es (Orientador externo)
objectives:
Over the past 100 years, Earth’s climate has become warmer and precipitation regimes have changed. Can we predict the effects of these changes on biodiversity? 

This open proposal is to take place within the frame of an interdisciplinary collaboration with the Miguel B. Araújo lab (http://www.maraujolab.com) in Madrid, and Universidade de Évora (http://www.catedra.uevora.pt/rui-nabeiro/), both coordinated by Miguel B. Araújo (http://www.maraujolab.com/people/miguel-araujo/).

Research in the Miguel B. Araújo lab seeks improving understanding of the key mechanisms governing the distribution of life on Earth, with strong focus on species distributions. Basic research in the lab tends to feed into the development of models to forecast species distributional dynamics under climate- and land-use change scenarios. To address these questions, large climate and species distributions databases are integrated with descriptions of behavioural and physiological traits of species, molecular phylogenies, and the fossil record. Most research in the lab involves statistical analyses of ecological data, including data mining, bioclimatic modeling, and mathematical simulations, but large-scale experiments, including microcosm and mesocosm experiments, are now being devised for testing models and theory on species distributions and species coexistence.

The lab has several ongoing interdisciplinary projects, and seeks students and researchers with background in Informatics, for contributing in the areas of Data and Software Science and Engineering. The task are to be adapted to the background and interests of the candidate.
requirements: Successful completion of a Masters level course on the technical area (in Informatics) that is being applied in the chosen task.

title: Dissertação: Estudo das Vulnerabilidades XS-Search e XSLeaks
objectives:
XS-Search e XSLeaks são duas vulnerabilidades recentes que consistem em explorar fragilidades da construção da Internet por forma a obter informação privada acerca dos utilizadores. Um caso conhecido é a medição do tempo que uma página/imagem demora a carregar e assim inferir se essa imagem já foi previamente acedida pelo utilizador ou não.

O objectivo desta tese é o estudo das vulnerabilidades acima indicadas, possível impacto, e possíveis medidas que a atenuem.
requirements: Segurança em Software.

title: Dissertação: Rendezvous and Formation Decentralized Algorithms for Multi-agent Systems
objectives: Nesta tese de mestrado propõem-se estudar vários algoritmos distribuídos para resolver o problema de rendezvous para os casos em que a rede não é conexa e a comunicação pode ser limitada aos equipamentos receberem informação de localização dos seus vizinhos imediatos. A inexistência de informação sobre toda a rede como quantos nós existem ou a sua topologia dificultam a tarefa de desenhar algoritmos que possam fornecer garantias de convergência. Os algoritmos a desenhar terão de satisfazer o compromisso entre velocidade de convergência e a necessidade de exploração para encontrar outros clusters da rede. No decorrer desta tese, planeia-se utilizar resultados recentes sobre a convergência de sistemas dinâmicos estocásticos para garantir convergência almost surely ou em sentido mean square. Outra abordagem será desenhar algoritmos com base em teoria de jogos de forma puramente descentralizada e sem comunicação onde a informação que os agentes recebem serve para calcular a utility actual da formação.

title: Projeto: A new Touch on Chemistry
location: O trabalho será realizado no (GAIPS) - INESC-ID, IST-Taguspark e no Laboratório de Jogos do IST- Taguspark.
objectives: O objectivo desta tese é continuar o desenvolvimento do jogo Touch on Chemistry que pretende ensinar Química Orgânica e alunos do secundário. Um video que demonstra a versão atual pode ser encontrado aqui: https://www.facebook.com/LabJogosIST/videos/356169271623554/. A versão atual usa o dispositivo Leap Motion para permitir a interação de “mãos livres” para manipulação direta dos objetos do jogo (ex: átomos e moléculas). Pretende-se começar a usar um par de luvas interativas (Avatar VR - https://avatarvr.es/) para o mesmo efeito de forma a melhorar a experiência de interação. Para além disso será analisada a usabilidade atual do jogo e pretende-se melhorar os aspectos de interação que sejam necessários. O conteúdo do jogo em termos de desafios apresentados será atualizado com a ajuda de professores de Química Orgânica. Espera-se a realização de testes com utilizadores para avaliar a qualidade do jogo.
requirements: De preferência ter conhecimentos sobre conceitos e tecnologias de jogos e design de interação, em particular em Realidade Virtual.

title: Dissertação: Multiresolution Hopfield network
objectives:
“A Hopfield network is a form of recurrent artificial neural network popularized by John Hopfield in 1982, but described earlier by Little in 1974]Hopfield nets serve as content-addressable memory systems with binary threshold nodes. They are guaranteed to converge to a local minimum, but will sometimes converge to a false pattern (wrong local minimum) rather than the stored pattern (expected local minimum). Hopfield networks also provide a model for understanding human memory.” Wikipedia

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopfield_network


We will investigate a multi-resolution Hopfield Network using either OR or AND aggregation to store patterns. We will preform empirical experiments. (MATLAB or Mathematica or Python)

Investigate the "energy", E, of the network in relation to the resolution

Joao Sacramento and Andreas Wichert: Tree-like hierarchical associative memory structures, Neural Networks, 24 (2): 143-147, 2011
Sudarshan, B., and R. Manjunatha. "Multi-resolution architecture of graded memory." Emerging Research in Electronics, Computer Science and Technology (ICERECT), 2015 International Conference on. IEEE, 2015.
requirements: You should like mathematics, and like to preform experiments on a computer.You should be prepared to read scientific papers.

supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
title: [Dissertação] Criação de música a partir de sons ambientes, uma abordagem da Criatividade Computacional
observations:
This thesis involves an informal collaboration with the Musicology Department of the FCSH of Nova University
This Thesis is for Student nº 83546 Pedro Quintas
objectives:
Sound and Music Generation is an interesting topic of Computational Creativity and Musicology. While the discussion of whether machines can create creative artifacts is heated and fierce we focus on Inspiration: we pick an artifact deemed  as creative or a possible source of inspiration by a human expert and transform it in an artistic artifact.
In this Thesis we aim at sound and music generation from ambient sounds. This path has been traveled by human composers in the 20th century, such as John Cage - Imaginary Landscape No. 1, 1939 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p-3iLnXV90s

First, an overview study of existing proposals on sound generation from ambient sounds, will be conducted, such as electroacoustic music and other music currents. Then a computational approach from the music composition domain will be explored. These will be further elaborated by the use of genetic algorithms or other techniques suitable for computational creativity.
requirements: This Thesis is for Student nº 83546 Pedro Quintas

title: Dissertation: Towards Correct Software-Defined Networks
observations: This project will be co-advised by Luis Pedrosa (new Professor at DEI, starting September 2019) and Fernando Ramos (Professor at FCUL)
objectives:
Managing a network is surprisingly hard. To specify their high-level requirements (e.g., "only hosts X and Y should be allowed to communicate with server Z"), network operators have to devise low-level configurations that specify the behavior of hundreds of devices running complex distributed protocols. As a result, a single misconfiguration can bring down the entire network infrastructure.

Proposed just 10 years ago, Software Defined Networking (SDN) [1] has started to change this undesirable state of affairs. By logically centralizing control in the SDN controller, it changed the paradigm: from configurable to programmable networks. Today, several large scale infrastructures employ SDN, ranging from cloud companies [2, 3] to enterprises [4] and service providers [5].

The emergence of SDN and the increasing scale of networking infrastructure -- and the raising concerns about the brittleness of its configuration and control -- has led to a spur of interest in network verification and synthesis. Network verification approaches (e.g., [6-9] are used to check a configuration with respect to operators' requirements, whereas synthesis [10-13] aims to derive correct network configurations out of high-level objectives.

In this thesis we will explore these techniques in the context of SDN. Our specific goal is to design, implement, and evaluate an SDN controller that is guaranteed to be correct with respect to some high-level specification (e.g., "the network has no loops"). This project will require the development of software modules for an existing SDN controller (e.g., ONOS, https://onosproject.org/), and its integration with existing verification tools and techniques (e.g., those employed in [9])

References:

SDN
[1] D. Kreutz et al., "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey," in Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 103, no. 1, pp. 14-76, Jan. 2015
[2] S. Jain, B4: experience with a globally-deployed software defined wan, SIGCOMM'13
[3] C.-Y. Hong et al., Achieving high utilization with software-driven WAN, SIGCOMM'13
[4] T. Koponen et al., Network Virtualization in Multi-tenant Datacenters, NSDI'14
[5] http://about.att.com/innovation/sdn

title: Dissertação: Intelligent Student Feedback
objectives: The objective is to develop a system that will automatically help students with debugging their software projects (in courses such as IAED or ASA).  As of now, students only get very limited feedback when submitting their projects. Upon submission,  systems such as Mooshak only tell the student which tests have passed and which have failed. However, it is often difficult for the student to find the actual bug based on this information alone. The objective of this thesis will be to develop a system that will provide the students with a more informative test case that will help the students to debug the project.

title: Dissertação: ITLingo/GenBIS: Produção Automática de Aplicações de Negócio
objectives:
Trabalho enquadrado nas temáticas de Engenharia de Requisitos, Desenvolvimento Baseado em Modelos, Desenho de Aplicações de Negócio (business information systems), Aplicações Web Responsive. No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo tem sido definido linguagens textuais para especificação rigorosa de requisitos (linguagem RSL, Requirements Specification Language) e de aplicações de software (linguagem ASL, Application Specification Language), cuja informação preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de  https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL. Pretende-se explorar e desenvolver mecanismos de produção automática de protótipos aplicacionais de sistemas de informação a partir das especificações rigorosas em RSL e ASL, e tirando partido das tecnologias de validação, transformação e geração automática de modelos em código.

No âmbito deste projeto pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas da engenharia de requisitos, arquitecturas de software, aplicações Web responsive, e desenvolvimento baseado em modelos. 

O aluno deverá realizar as seguintes tarefas principais: 
(i) Investigação inicial: Conhecimento geral das tecnologias de suporte a Apps Web responsive (e.g., CSS, HTML5, Javascript, TypeScript, Angular2, ASP.NET Core); Conhecimento de linguagens para desenho de UI de aplicações, e.g., notações do tipo IFML, Wireframe; Conhecimento das linguagens de especificação rigorosa de aplicações de software (e.g., RSL e ASL).
(ii) Aspectos de desenho e desenvolvimento a considerar: Definir e implementar extensões à linguagem de especificação de requisitos RSL, nomeadamente para permitir a especificação genérica de UIs (user interfaces). Definir e implementar mecanismos de transformação de modelo-modelo e modelo-código de forma a produzir semi-automaticamente aplicações de negócio, e.g., para o stack ASP.NET Core MVC (do lado do servidor) e Angular2 (do lado do cliente), ou outro stack de desenvolvimento a definir.
(iii) Validação e avaliação dos resultados obtidos, com base na aplicação a cenários concretos a definir.
(iv) Avaliação e discussão dos resultados.

title: Dissertation: Improving database performance through symbolic execution
objectives:
Modern databases systems need to deal with an increasingly large amount of concurrent and potentially conflicting transactions.
Hence identifying conflicts and scheduling transactions in such a way that those are minimized is essential for achieving good performance.

The objective of this thesis proposal is to leverage symbolic execution and judicious scheduling techniques to improve the classification and scheduling of transactions in a replicated database environment.


Bibliography:
[1] Fine-grained Transaction Scheduling in Replicated Databases via Symbolic Execution. Pedro Raminhas, Miguel Matos and Paolo Romano. 12th EuroSys Doctoral Workshop (EuroDW 2018)
[2] Calvin: fast distributed transactions for partitioned database systems.Thomson,A et al. In: Proceedings of the 2012 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data. 2012.
[3] Schism: a Workload-Driven Approach to Database Replication and Partitioning. In Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment 3. 2010.
[4] A Survey of Symbolic Execution Techniques, Roberto Baldoni, Emilio Coppa, Daniele Cono D'Elia, Camil Demetrescu, Irene Finocchi. arXiv, 2016.
[5] Scalable replication in database clusters. M. Patino-Martinez, R. Jimºenez-Peris, B. Kemme, and G. Alonso. Distributed Computing. 2000.
[6] A static analysis framework for detecting sql injection vulnerabilities. Fu, X., Lu, X., Peltsverger, B., Chen, S., Qian, K., and Tao, L. In International Computer Software and Applications Conference - Volume 01. 2007
requirements:
The student should be familiar with advanced distributed systems concepts.Frequency of DAD and SEC is a plus.
Good programming skills.
The thesis should be done as full time (excluding, naturally, other course duties).

title: Dissertação: Auto Patching Security Vulnerabilities - Generating of invariants
objectives:
Automatically repairing security vulnerabilities has the potential to secure a software system against unknown/known attacks. We propose to do that by leveraging a three phase approach. First, we will use (non-malicious) executions of the system to learn a model of what constitutes normal behaviour. This will be done using work from the qualitative reasoning world as well as program invariants in order to capture such behaviour. At run-time, execution that fall outside of expected behaviour will lead to the program to terminate the execution and notify the developers (e.g., via a PR) of an issue.

The outcome of this thesis is an artifact that will help during the learning and deployment phase. Ideally, the tool would integrate a version control management systems (such as github) in order to open an issue when potential attacks are observed.
requirements: Segurança em Software.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: (Dissertação) Gamification for MOOC online courses
location: INOV INESC Inovação - Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 7º andar
observations:
Para mais informações sff mande um mail para mms@tecnico.ulisboa.pt

Tese acompanhada pela aluna de doutoramento Rita Marques.

Tese realizada no âmbito da criação de um MOOC.
objectives:
The objectives for this master thesis are the following: describe the problem and propose and evaluate a solution. The problem should be defined, and the value of a solution justified. The solution should be a design research artefact (constructs, models, methods, or instantiations) that requires knowledge of theory. The evaluation should be based on a demonstration that solves one or more instances of the problem.

The problem is that dropout rates in online courses is very high, usually 95% or even more. Although there are other approaches for reducing this rate (such as peer-review) in fact most students never finish the online courses, thus having part of the cost but little or even no benefits. In this thesis the student will start by performing a literature review about gamification in short online courses (also known as MOOCs) and then propose a few gamification techniques that will be implemented in a real-world MOOC that will be created in the first semester about agile project management. The evaluation will be based on that MOOC with hundreds of real-world students. The co-supervisor (Prof. Daniel Gonçalves) teaches a "gamified" course at Técnico, and is an expert on gamification.

DEPENDING ON THE COMMITMENT SHOWED BY THE STUDENT, A MONTHLY RESEARCH GRANT MAY BE OFFERED
requirements: The student must dedicate at least three full working days per week to the thesis, and manage the thesis as a project using Scrum.

title: Projeto: Whaleterpreter machine learning, cetaceans, internet of things, acoustics
location: ITI / LARSYS fieldwork to be conducted in Madeira with support form a research project
observations: If you get sea sick this is probably not a good project for you :-)
objectives: While sea mammals use vocal calls for communication, we are still far from understanding them. Thesis involves the collection and analysis of acoustic signals obtained from offshore locations using IoT tags or buoys. Post processing will be implemented for detecting sound, noise reduction, adding acoustic effects, while inspecting spectrograms to understand and discriminate the vocal calls of cetaceans (e.g. clicks, moans, whistles) as well as per taxa (e.g dolphin, whale, monk seal) and behaviour (e.g. socializing, hunting, etc). Advanced statistics will be performed using supervised learning, machine learning, neural networks. Ideally, analysis and prediction of the trained models will be collected and compared using the low-cost microcomputers deployed in-situ. Intended activities will be performed in close collaboration with marine biologists from Observatorio Oceanografico and ITI LARSyS.
requirements: Mobile application development with Android or iOS. Microcontroller programming (e.g. Arduino, PyCom).

title: Dissertação: GnuTLS-SGX: a port of the GnuTLS library for Intel SGX
objectives:
Transport Layer Security (TLS) refers to a cryptographic protocol that offers end-to-end communications security over networks, namely communication confidentiality and data integrity. Several versions of the protocol are widely used for Internet communications and online transactions, among other applications. Therefore, multiple implementations of TLS have been proposed as commercial and open source cryptographic libraries, e.g. OpenSSL, Amazon s2n, MbedTLS, Apple CoreTLS, Mozilla NSS, WolfSSL, or GnuTLS. In the latter years, vulnerabilities have been found in several of these libraries, which poses critical security issues to many applications.

Intel Software Guard Extensions (Intel SGX) is a name for an Intel architecture extension designed to increase the security of software by creating Trusted Execution Environments (secure enclaves in the Intel terminology). Using this technology, it becomes possible for user-level and operating system code to define private regions of memory, the enclaves, whose contents are protected and unable to be either read or saved by any process outside the enclave itself, including processes running at higher privilege levels. As such, nowadays several cryptographic libraries provide support for Intel SGX, such as MbedTLS or wolfSSL. However, that is not the case of GnuTLS, a cryptographic library widely used in Linux.

The main goal of this work is to develop a port of the GnuTLS library for Intel SGX, named GnuTLS-SGX.

title: Dissertation: Reproducible testing of distributed systems
objectives:
Nowadays, large-scale systems are composed of  10s to 100s and even 1000s of nodes that are distributed across the globe. To ensure availability and reliability, such systems must be resilient to faults (such as crashing, network partitioning, etc..) that are common in production environments. 

Unfortunately, debugging and testing the fault-tolerance guarantees of distributed systems is a notoriously complex task.
For instance, one might test the same system two times with the same fault and observed different behaviors - for instance, one time the fault leads to an error in the systems, and the other time the system behaves correctly.
This is due to the non-deterministic nature of distributed systems, where the same fault may not always hamper their correctness or performance. Accordingly, to ensure rigorous testing, we need to be able to deterministically reproduce faults that persist within the system. 

The goal of this thesis proposal is to explore the internal state of a system (via system calls, I/O, logs, etc.) to synchronize fault injection with the state, in order to enable engineers to correctly reproduce - and fix- incorrect system behavior.

Bibliography:
[1] "Finding Crash-Consistency Bugs with Bounded Black-Box Crash Testing", OSDI '18
[2] "Correlated Crash Vulnerabilities", OSDI' 16
[2] "Lineage-driven Fault Injection", SIGMOD '15
[3] "FCatch: Automatically Detecting Time-of-fault Bugs in Cloud Systems", ASPLOS '18
[4] "Automating Failure Testing Research at Internet Scale" , SoCC '16
[5] "ChaosMonkey", https://github.com/Netflix/chaosmonkey
[6] "An empirical study on crash recovery bugs in large-scale distributed systems", ESEC/FSE '18
requirements:
The student should be familiar with advanced distributed systems concepts.Frequency of DAD and SEC is a plus.
Good programming skills.
The thesis should be done as full time (excluding, naturally, other course duties).

title: Dissertation - DAN: Digitally Augmented Notebooks
location: You will be part of the VIMMI (https://vimmi.inesc-id.pt/) group at INESC-ID and you will conduct your work at Taguspark (Oeiras). You will have access to João Lourenço Fernandes laboratory (http://lab-jlf.ist.utl.pt/).
observations: Members of the team will support you as needed regarding technical skills (software or hardware). This work will be conducted in collaboration with Grupo para Necessidades Educativas Especiais do IST and Centro de Investigação Interdisciplinar Egas Moniz.
objectives:
This proposal is within the field of human-computer interaction.

Digital self-tracking technologies offer many potential benefits over self-tracking with paper notebooks. However, they are often too rigid to support people’s practical and emotional needs in everyday settings. For example, prior works suggest that people abandon consumer technologies (e.g. Nike+, Fitbit) over time because of a lack of personally meaningful insights and switch to paper notebooks to avoid unintended effects and to overcome technological boundaries. The material qualities and affordances of pencil and paper provide unique physical values and support experiences of ownership, control, and joy.

The Internet of Things and the ubiquitous availability of computing power makes it possible for any object, including paper notebooks, to be connected to the Internet and send/receive data.

In this work, you will leverage an existing prototype that augments paper notebooks with computing power, enabling users to associate a rate (from 1 to 5) to their personal notes. Such functionality enables users to bridge the gap between quantitative and qualitative data; that is, bridge the gap between digital and analogue data. Each journal entry in the notebook can have a digital rating, allowing transitions from analogue to digital and from digital to analogue. Images of the existing physical prototype below:

1) https://www.dropbox.com/s/vn90ogv8y6vqxf4/dan1.jpg?dl=0
2) https://www.dropbox.com/s/u7s0yymlpxmuk9q/dan2.jpg?dl=0
3) https://www.dropbox.com/s/887hwiehbanso8f/dan3.jpg?dl=0

Your work will focus on developing the visualizations, app, and platform to support the seamless transition between analogue and digital data, and vice-versa. This will empower users to collect meaningful data, adopt reflective behaviours, and support communication with others. Such tools will be validated by deploying them in field studies and collect users’ daily experiences in two domains: education and health.

Tasks that you will undertake include:
1) Literature review;
2) Get acquainted with the current prototype;
3) Design self-reflection visualizations;
4) Develop interactive platform;
5) Deploy augmented diaries and conduct field studies in, at least, two domains: disabled college students’ experiences, and family-related experiences of stroke survivors.
6) Write your master thesis.
 
In addition to your master thesis, you are expected to advance the state of the art in the field of human-computer interaction and submit a paper to an international conference or journal.
requirements: Preference for students with good technical and social interaction skills.

title: Dissertação: Blended Workflow relaxing domain constraints
observations: More info about the project http://socialsoftware.github.io/blended/
objectives:
The Blended Workflow project fuses an activity-based approach with a goal-based approach. Its environment allows end users to follow a standard pre-defined behaviour when performing their work (following an activity-based view), but to deviate whenever an unexpected situation occurs (following a goal-based view). The Blended Workflow engine is responsible to keep the two different views of any workflow instance synchronised so that end users can decide at any time which view to use to perform their work.

Introduce in the Blended Workflow execution model the ability to relax its data dependencies in order to augment its flexibility, while preserving some level of consistency.
requirements:
- State of the art on adaptive workflow and flexibility mechanisms- Define the relax dependencies semantics
- Extend the runtime engine to support the new features
- Reimplementation of the Blended Workflow engine using the event source architecture

supervisors: Luís Miguel de Oliveira e Silva (50%)
title: Dissertation: A RayTracing-based platform for Scientific Visualization of Plasma Physics Simulation
observations: Thesis in partnership with the Group of Lasers and Plasmas (GoLP) from IST.
objectives:
At the Group of Lasers and Plasmas (GoLP) of Instituto de Plasmas e Fusão Nuclear at Instituto Superior Técnico, researchers use Particle-in-Cell (PIC) method-based simulations to model plasma with little or no approximations. PIC simulations solve the smallest scales of the plasma, so simulating large systems (where dynamical scales are much larger than the smallest scales) is computationally demanding. For this reason, these simulations are massively parallel, and run on some of the largest supercomputers available worldwide. These simulations produce multidimensional grid and particle data sets that generally exceed several gigabytes per file, making their analysis and visualization non-trivial.
Thus, the objective of this thesis is produce a Ray Tracing algorithm for photorealistic scientific visualization of results of the mentioned numerical simulations. By using the latest RTX platform provided by Nvidia, it should be possible to navigate  through these visualizations at interactive framerates. Technologies likeTuring-based GPU, CUDA and OpTix from Nvidia, as well as DXR from Microsoft, will be potential candidates for this thesis' work development. Different demos will be produced and will show numerical simulations of plasmas in the vicinity of compact astrophysical objects such as neutron stars and black holes, as well as of plasmas produced with intense lasers in the laboratory and used to create compact particle accelerators.
requirements: Disciplines in the area of Computer Graphics, like AVT and P3D

title: Dissertation: Impedance learning in physical human-robot interaction
location: Assistive Robotics Laboratory of the Department of Mechanical Engineering
objectives:
The objective of this thesis is to design and implement a biologically inspired learning architecture for human physical interaction with a KUKA light weight robot. 
The basic scenario in that of co-manipulation. An operator performs an interaction task with a tool, and the robot tracks both the kinematics and the force/moment interaction. 
The thesis will consist in exploring different learning approaches, in order for the robot to take over the task that was just learned. 


Referências:
Human Robotics, Burdet et al., MIT Press, 2013.

supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
title: [Dissertação] Focar a atenção em subconjuntos de objectos em streams de imagens
observations: Para mais informação contactar H. Sofia Pinto sofia(at)inesc-id.pt (http://ontol.inesc-id.pt/~sofia/) ou Alexandre Bernardino alex(at)isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt (http://welcome.isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/author/alexandrejosemalheiro/)
objectives:
O seguimento automático de múltiplos objectos em imagens está na base de importantes aplicações em multimedia, video-vigilância, jogos por computador, metrologia, etc. Este problema pode ser decomposto em dois passos: (i) o passo de detecção de objectos, onde numa única imagem são detectados os objectos e as suas localizações, e (ii) o passo de associação de dados onde os objectos detectados numa imagem são associados a objectos numa imagem consecutiva para manter a sua identidade ao longo do tempo. No entanto, este é um problema muito complexo devido a objectos que aparecem e desaparecem da imagem, cruzamentos entre objectos, ruído na detecção de objectos, variações bruscas de movimento, entre outros. No contexto de uma tese em curso está-se a desenvolver uma solução que mitigue e minimize esses problemas e permita seguir peixes em aquários densamente povoados.
Em alguns cenários, quando o número de objectos que se está a seguir ao mesmo tempo é muito grande, pode ser difícil a um observador externo conseguir perceber e seguir o movimento de um objecto particular num determinado vídeo ou stream de imagens. Por exemplo, no aquário principal do oceanário,  os biologos têm dificuldade em seguir um determinado espécimen dado o enorme número de peixes que co-habitam no mesmo espaço e por estes estarem em constante movimento.
O objectivo deste trabalho consiste em desenvolver uma solução que permita focar a atenção em subconjuntos de objectos em streams de imagens, eliminando os objectos que não interessam num determinado momento/situação/cenário. Neste caso, a tarefa é eliminar das imagens alguns dos peixes que não nos interessam para conseguirmos focar a atenção em apenas um ou os que foram identificados como interessantes de seguir.  Por exemplo, um biólogo marítimo poderia deste modo, aperceber-se das zonas preferidas por uma determinada espécie ao longo do dia ou das situações em que o peixe está envolvido (alimentação, dia/noite, rituais de acasalamento, etc).
requirements: O/A candidato/a deverá ter bons conhecimentos de processamento de imagem e visão e aprendizagem automática, e estar confortável com a programação C/C++ e/ou Python.Este trabalho pode envolver filmagens no Oceanário de Lisboa fora do horário normal de funcionamento.

title: Dissertation: Shout-out-Suggestions: Nonvisual Word Completion Interfaces
observations:
This work will be conducted in a collaboration with Raquel and Martin Sain Foundation.

You can check our previous research related to nonvisual mobile text input: http://web.ist.utl.pt/hugo.nicolau/project/textentry.html, http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/hugo.nicolau/project/wordcompletion.html


You will be part of the Visualization and Intelligent Multimodal Interfaces group at INESC-ID.
objectives:
In recent years, mobile text-entry has experienced numerous innovations leading to greater input speeds and lower error rates. One such leap was word completion, which is familiar to anyone using a modern smartphone. During the typing process the device will suggest the most probable word, allowing users to correct misspelled words or complete them without having to type the remaining characters. Word completion and auto-correct can be beneficial for most users, however the greatest gains are seen by users with slower text-entry rates, such as blind people, whom may struggle to make key selections.

While much work has been published on nonvisual mobile text input in recent years [1-4], there is still a lack of support for nonvisual suggestion selection on these devices, limiting the success of word completion solutions. Where a sighted person is able to quickly scan the entire display for input feedback, content changes, error notifications or auto-complete suggestions; a blind user receives only feedback for a single element at a given time.

In this dissertation, you will: 1) understand the fundamental challenges of nonvisual mobile word completion, 2) design and develop alternative nonvisual word completion interfaces based on [5] (NOT the underlying algorithms), and 3) evaluate the proposed solutions.

In addition to you master thesis, we will advance the state of the art in the field of mobile accessibility and submit a paper to an international conference or journal.

[1] Hugo Nicolau, Kyle Montague, Tiago Guerreiro, André Rodrigues, and Vicki L. Hanson. 2015. Typing Performance of Blind Users: An Analysis of Touch Behaviors, Learning Effect, and In-Situ Usage. In Proceedings of the 17th International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers & Accessibility (ASSETS '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 273-280. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2700648.2809861

[2] João Guerreiro, André Rodrigues, Kyle Montague, Tiago Guerreiro, Hugo Nicolau, and Daniel Gonçalves. 2015. TabLETS Get Physical: Non-Visual Text Entry on Tablet Devices. In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 39-42. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2702123.2702373

[3] Daniel Trindade, André Rodrigues, Tiago Guerreiro, and Hugo Nicolau. 2018. Hybrid-Brailler: Combining Physical and Gestural Interaction for Mobile Braille Input and Editing. In Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '18). ACM, New York, NY, USA, Paper 27, 12 pages. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3173601

[4] Hugo Nicolau, André Rodrigues, André Santos, Tiago Guerreiro, Kyle Montague, and João Guerreiro. 2019. The Design Space of Nonvisual Word Completion. In The 21st International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility (ASSETS '19). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 249-261. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/3308561.3353786
requirements: Preference for students with experience in Android development and good social interaction skills.

title: [Dissertation] Event-driven network programming
observations: Esta dissertação será orientada pelo Prof. Fernando Ramos, que passará a ser docente do DEI a partir do 2 semestre de 19/20.
objectives:
The rise of programmable network switches (such as Intel/Barefoot Tofino [1], the world’s fastest) and of a language to program them (such as P4 [2]) has sparked an interest in developing new applications for packet processing in these devices. Unfortunately, current programming models allow developers to express packet processing on a synchronous packet-by-packet basis, a model that does not naturally fit many modern network applications.

To address this problem, S. Ibanez et al. [3] have proposed event-driven switch architectures, which provide a programming model that explicitly exposes a rich set of switch-based events to the P4 programmer, alleviating many of the key limitations of existing architectures, and enabling more interesting packet processing applications.

The goal of this project is to design and implement real network applications that explore the capabilities of event-driven architectures, and evaluate them with real networking hardware. As part of the project the student will have the opportunity to work with cutting edge networking technology, including programming a NetFGPA [4] and/or a Barefoot Tofino switch [1] using P4 [2].

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos (who recently joined the IST as Associate Prof.) and Gianni Antichi (Assistant Prof. at Queen Mary University of London, and co-author of [3]). Steve Ibanez from Stanford University (lead of the P4-NetFPGA project and co-author of [3]) will also collaborate in the project.  

[1] Barefoot Tofino: World's fastest P4-programmable Ethernet switch ASICs, https://www.barefootnetworks.com/products/brief-tofino/
[2] https://p4.org
[3] S. Ibanez et al., Event-Driven Packet Processing, HotNets’19
[4] https://netfpga.org/
requirements: The students must have a good background in distributed systems.

title: PROJECTO: Real-time Data Visualization in Mobile App for Agricultural Sensors.
observations: Tese em colaboração com a empresa Chilltime <https://www.chilltime.com/>
objectives:
This work aims at developing a mobile app to visualize information retrieved from sensors in crops. This app will allow users to view relevant data collected by the sensors in the monitored crops. It should show temperature, humidity/temperature ration on the soil, humidity of the leaves, and water consumption. The proposed solution will allow the visualization of this information in two different views: tables and graphics. The visualization functionalities will be complemented by a notification/alert system so the user can learn about the state of its crops as well as when the next watering will take place. 
React Native will be used to develop a mobile solution, built on top of an API that will connect to the existing backend of the current web-based version of the app.

supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (100%)
title: Dissertation: 2D Breast Cancer Diagnosis Explainable Visualizations
objectives:
This project proposes the development of an explainable recommendation User Interface (UI) that seeks to maximize exploration within the breast cancer diagnosis scope. While maintaining recommendation relevance, the purpose of this UI will take advantage of several outputs (DenseNet [1]). The outputs will model the severity score of the lesion for each image of the patient, as well as along with the patient's pathology. The UI must address the visualization of a Multi-Modality (MM) strategy for a set of two 2D Medical Imaging (MI) technologies [4, 5]. Such Multi-Modalities are both (1) MammoGraphy (MG) containing both Cranio-Caudal (CC) and Mediolateral Oblique (MLO) views; and (2) UltraSound (US). The immediate work ahead is to develop a complete interactive UI for recommendations based on our available outputs. With this, we aim to understand the effects of an increase in exploration, as well as the benefits of explainability. This work uses a well-known literature topic called eXplainable AI (XAI) [2, 3] that will be of chief importance to the job scope. To accomplish this goal the proposed work has two following stages.

(1) Data curation and queries of the needed datasets:

While we have a big amount of data, this data must be first curated. Also, it is important to first develop the set of queries that will promote the information visualization of that data. As we are working with MI technologies, the related queries are mainly based on acquiring those images on the datasets and respective information. For each image, a set of queries regarding the DenseNet [1] outputs, breast severity, and pathology of each image must be formulated. In the end, the first stage is to understand and formulated our datasets so that it will be easy to follow the next stage.

(2) Development of the 2D image heatmaps:

To this end, a UI will be developed to show severity and pathology evolutions along with the images to a radiologist. For instance, the MG images, are presented in the UI, and a query for MG heatmap representation is presented. This will provide radiologists an explainability model for the visualization of the lesion segmentation. Nextly, the UI must provide also the second modality (i.e., US), formulating the same heatmap visualization about the existence of lesions. Two color scales must address both severity and pathology evolutions of the breast across the image. The scales must provide each radiologist with an intuitive and explainable way to understand the level of severity and pathology information of each image.

Goals

Development of a system (UI) for explainable recommendations in the scope of the breast cancer diagnosis. The system must have an intuitive UI for the user. Also, must be a user-friendly interface that allows users to rapidly interpret several images on a MM basis. It is intended to develop a system to provide visual explainability of our DenseNet [1] outputs regarding the breast images in various visualization techniques. Responses of these visualization techniques (e.g., color heatmaps) are containing plenty of useful information that is extracted and analyzed by the clinicians for the purpose of analysis, detection, and diagnosis of breast lesions.

The imaging modalities to include in the work are:

- MammoGraphy (MG), including the views Cranio-Caudal (CC) and Mediolateral Oblique (MLO);

- UltraSound (US);

With protocol already signed with the Hospital Fernando Fonseca (HFF), it is intended that this system has two features: 

(i) - A novel strategy to provide explainability across breast cancer diagnosis;

Provide de user (clinician) an intuitive system with a more explainable technique for lesions detection than a naïve approach. This technique is important in multiple variables, such as understanding the patterns of both severity and pathology for each patient, as well as higher lesion findings.

(ii) - Perform a case study using the developed approach;

Based on the developed approach, perform a case study on a task of interpreting breast lesions on an image set. By describing the system setup in detail and discuss various design heuristics, including how to frame cost-effective visualizations posted to clinicians on the radiology room.



References

[1] Shah, M., Wang, D., Rubadue, C., Suster, D. and Beck, A., 2017, November. Deep learning assessment of tumor proliferation in breast cancer histological images. In 2017 IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM) (pp. 600-603). IEEE.

[2] Holzinger, A., Malle, B., Kieseberg, P., Roth, P.M., Müller, H., Reihs, R. and Zatloukal, K., 2017. Towards the augmented pathologist: Challenges of explainable-ai in digital pathology. arXiv preprint arXiv:1712.06657.

[3] Bharadhwaj, H., 2019, March. Explainable recommender system that maximizes exploration. In Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces: Companion (pp. 1-2). ACM.

[4] Calisto, F.M., Ferreira, A., Nascimento, J.C. and Gonçalves, D., 2017, October. Towards Touch-Based Medical Image Diagnosis Annotation. In Proceedings of the 2017 ACM International Conference on Interactive Surfaces and Spaces (pp. 390-395). ACM.

[5] Cardoso, M.J., Arbel, T., Carneiro, G., Syeda-Mahmood, T., Tavares, J.M.R., Moradi, M., Bradley, A., Greenspan, H., Papa, J.P., Madabhushi, A. and Nascimento, J.C. eds., 2017. Deep Learning in Medical Image Analysis and Multimodal Learning for Clinical Decision Support: Third International Workshop, DLMIA 2017, and 7th International Workshop, ML-CDS 2017, Held in Conjunction with MICCAI 2017, Québec City, QC, Canada, September 14, Proceedings (Vol. 10553). Springer.

title: [Dissertação] Espaço de Desenho para o uso de "Eye-tracking" em Videojogos com Múltiplos Agentes
objectives: A interação com videojogos através de tecnologias "eye-tracking" é um método em crescente expansão. Infelizmente, o seu uso é bastante limitado, focando-se maioritariamente no uso do olhar como cursor para seleção ou navegação em videojogos na primeira pessoa. O objetivo deste projeto é a análise de mecânicas de jogo em videojogos com múltiplos agentes (desporto, estratégia, etc.), e o redesenho e implementação destas usando "eye-tracking" quando apropriado.
requirements: - Programação associada com motores de jogos- Noções básicas de estudos de usabilidade

title: Dissertação: Scalable Program Synthesis
observations:
Miguel Terra-Neves, miguel.neves@outsystems.com

Tema de tese atribuida ao aluno Ricardo Brancas
objectives:
Program synthesis is one of the most central problems in the theory of
programming and one of the holy grail of computer science. The idea is
that the developer should only need to provide a specification of what
the program should do, and the computer should be responsible for
inferring an implementation that satisfies the specification. Program
synthesis has proved successful in various specific applications, the
most notable one being FlashFill, a function synthesizer for Microsoft
Excel spreadsheets. Despite its successes and the significant progress
achieved in recent years, modern program synthesizers suffer from severe
scalability issues due to the undecidable nature of the problem. In
fact, solving program synthesis is equivalent to solving second-order
logic. This MSc topic aims to push the boundaries of modern program
synthesizers by designing parallel/distributed solutions for the program
synthesis problem.

title: Dissertação – Mitigating churn in P2P storage systems
observations: Proposta apresentada no MEIC-A, MEIC-T e METI
objectives:
There have been several attempts to create distributed storage systems based on volunteer 
nodes organized in a P2P architecture. This could provide a free decentralized solution to storage 
issues. However, as is often the case in P2P environments, the high level of churn (node entry 
and exit rates) may lead to several storage problems: loss of files and unstable aggregate storage 
size. 
The work will consist of an initial study of existing P2P storage systems and how they manage the 
issue of storage capacity management under churn. The second stage is the design of an algorithm 
for the management of the aggregate storage space in P2P systems that takes advantage of several 
techniques such as sharding, compression and deduplication. The third stage is the 
implementation of such an algorithm and its evaluation, which should be done using either a 
simulation or an integration with an existing P2P storage system. Finally, a paper and the 
dissertation describing the work will be written.

supervisors: Teresa Maria Sá Ferreira Vazão Vasques (80%)
title: Dissertação: Internet of Drones – Drones para IoT
observations: Orientador: Teresa Vazão: teresa.vazao@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
Os drones tem vindo a ganhar enorme importância, existindo diversos domínios de aplicação em que poderão vir a ser usados, nomeadamente para recolha de informação de sensores,  entregas de encomendas, ou ações de busca e salvamento. É neste contexto que tem surgido, recentemente, uma área de investigação emergente - Internet of Drones - , cujo objetivo é a concepção de redes baseadas em drones que sirvam de base ao desenvolvimento de aplicações cooperativas. 
No contexto da presente tese, pretende-se criar um sistema de recolha de informação baseada em drones, que suporte ações de logística. No referido sistema, existe um conjunto de sensores espalhados por um armazém e o drone é responsável por recolher informação dos sensores, tendo por base um percurso previamente definido.  Um modelo inspirador deste tipo de sistema é o modelo de distribuição que a Amazon tem vindo a testar.

Pretende-se com a presente tese criar uma colaboração multidisciplinar, envolvendo um aluno de Engenharia e Gestão Industrial que será responsável pela elaboração do plano de negócios. A equipa, em conjunto deverá proceder às especificações do sistema e ao levantamento de requisitos., tendo em consideração aspetos de negócios e tecnológicos.
requirements: Solidos conhecimentos de redes, programação e sistemas Linux (Raspberry Pi). Gosto pelo trabalho em equipas multidisciplinares.

supervisors: Teresa Maria Sá Ferreira Vazão Vasques (100%)
specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Sistema de segurança para condutores de veiculos nao motorizados
observations:
Possibilidade de atribuição de bolsa, dependendo da qualidade do trabalho desenvolvido no projeto de tese.

Orientador: Teresa Vazão: teresa.vazao@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
A proliferação nas cidades de veiculos nao motorizados, tais como bicicletas e trotinetes electricas vem introduzir modificações significativas ao padrão de circulação. Estes veiculos não estando equipados com dispositvos de sensorização, não oferecem aos seus condutores informações sobre a envolvente, e esas informação é fundamental para a existencia de condução segura. 
Este trabalho tem por objetivo criar um sistema de sensorização que forneça aos condutores de veiculos nao motorizados informação sobre a sua envolvente, de forma a potenciar uma condução mais segura. O referido sistema sera desenvolvido com recurso a Raspberry Pis, equipados de dispositivos de sensorização e comunicação adequados.
requirements: Conhecimentos solidos de programação, sistemas operativos e redes. Gosto pela realização de projeto de engenharia

supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (50%)
specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Blockchain undo: panic button for stolen crypto-wallets
location: Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos, INESC-ID, Alameda
observations: Proposta elaborada com o estudante Filipe Miguel Fernandes Martins, 83458
objectives:
Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin have made the concept of blockchain popular. It is now possible to represent digital assets in a tamper-proof, consensus based ledger in a very decentralized architecture, where no single party has full control. The blockchain itself is a distributed ledger where currency transactions are stored (e.g., transfer x coins from A to B). The blockchains is supposed to be an unmodifiable, append-only, log of transactions. This is a well-accepted characteristic of existing blockchains, although there have been a few misguided proposals of allowing modifications to the blockchain, entirely breaking the concept.

Despite these misguided proposals, in some cases there is indeed the need to undo some transactions, e.g., when crypto-wallets are stolen. Because of time lengthy validation processes - mining - there is significant time between submitting a transaction and that transaction becoming part of the blockchain. This is weakness of the current protocols. However, it could be seen as an opportunity for creating transaction cancelling mechanisms, after they are submitted for inclusion in the blockchain , but before they are actually included. One specific benefit of this extension would be the ability to cancel a transaction issued by mistake or a “panic button” that cancels all pending transactions associated with a crypto-wallet under attack. 

Referências:
Morgen E. Peck. Blockchains: How They Work and Why They’ll Change the World. IEEE Spectrum 54(10), 2017.
Satoshi Nakamoto. Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System. October 31, 2008
David Matos, Miguel Pardal, and Miguel Correia. Rectify: Black-Box Intrusion Recovery in PaaS Clouds. In Proceedings of the 2017 ACM/IFIP/USENIX International Middleware Conference, Dec. 2017.
requirements:
Realização do projeto em tempo integral, 40 horas/semana (excepto cadeiras do curso).SIRS > 14
Blockchain enthusiast

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: Co-Reference Resolution in Portuguese and Spanish Texts
[Dissertação] Optimization of UAV message delivery trajectories in partitioned Mobile Ad-hoc Networks using Deep Queue Learning
location: INESC-ID, Rua Alves Redol, nº 9, 1000-029 Lisboa
objectives: Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs) are networks formed exclusively of mobile nodes, without a fixed infrastructure. Through multihop communication, a message can reach receivers that are located beyond the direct range of the sender, since the message will be forwarded hop-by-hop by other mobile nodes forming a path between those communication endpoints. However, due to node mobility, the MANET may be partitioned with groups of nodes becoming isolated from each other, i.e., with all the nodes of one group moving beyond the radio range of other groups. In this case, no direct routing path exists between the separate groups and the messages must be delivered by nodes occasionally roaming between the groups or deployed on purpose to serve as messengers. This project assumes that the messenger role is played by Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), which will perform message delivery by flying between the groups. Such network thus becomes a Delay Tolerant Network (DTN). In order to minimize the needs for refueling as well as the message delivery delay, the paths taken by the UAVs must be optimized.
requirements: Good programming skills, motivation to research, basic machine learning knowledge.

title: Dissertação: Machine learning for logic circuit synthesis
objectives: The objective is to develop a system that will try to automatically synthesize logic circuits using machine learning methods. Logic circuits are composed of logic gates (e.g. AND, OR) and eventually calculate complex functions (e.g. summation). Automatically synthesizing small circuits, given a their specification, is a challenging task. The objective of this thesis will be to use machine learning or evolutionary approaches to come up with such designs automatically.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertation: Construction of Certified Software
objectives:
The goal of this project is to explore how the proof assistant Coq [BC13,Chl13] can be used to develop certified software (i.e. software that satisfies a specification). Coq is a proof assistant that allows us to write programs in a functional language called Gallina. Since it is a proof assistant, it also allows us to prove properties about these programs. Moreover, it is possible to extract these programs into languages such as OCaml and Haskell. The goal of this project is to explore this idea and apply it in areas where certification is desirable. Examples of this approach include the creation of certified Linux PAM modules [FJMB17] and certified file systems [CZC+15].

Application areas that can be explored include digital forensics (e.g. file carvers), authentication software (e.g. PAM modules), and smart contracts (e.g. can we build Solidity contracts immune to certain classes of vulnerabilities?). Students can choose any application area, but this has to be discussed with the supervisor. 

In the context of this project, CertiCoq [AAM+17] will also be explored. With Certicoq, the code extraction process is also verified, thus increasing confidence in the final artefacts.


[AAM+17] Abhishek Anand, Andrew Appel, Greg Morrisett, Zoe Paraskevopoulou, Randy Pollack, Olivier Savary Bélanger, Matthieu Sozeau, and Matthew Weaver. Certicoq: A verified compiler for
coq. In The Third International Workshop on Coq for Programming Languages (CoqPL), 2017.
[BC13] Yves Bertot and Pierre Castéran. Interactive theorem proving and program development: Coq’Art: the calculus of inductive
constructions. Springer Science & Business Media, 2013.
[Chl13] Adam Chlipala. Certified programming with dependent types: a pragmatic introduction to the Coq proof assistant. MIT Press, 2013.
[CZC+15] Haogang Chen, Daniel Ziegler, Tej Chajed, Adam Chlipala, M Frans Kaashoek, and Nickolai Zeldovich. Using crash Hoare logic for certifying the fscq file system. In
Proceedings of the 25th Symposium on Operating Systems Principles, pages 18–37. ACM, 2015.
[FJMB17] Joao F Ferreira, Saul A Johnson, Alexandra Mendes, and Phillip J Brooke. Certified password quality—a case study using Coq and Linux pluggable authentication modules.
Lecture Notes in Computer Science, 2017.
requirements:
Students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in functional programming
3. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
4. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Reclamações Inteligentes
observations: Este tema será realizado em cooperação com a Imprensa Nacional - Casa da Moeda (INCM), sendo oferecido um estágio remunerado durante a realização do mesmo. Coorientação externa do Dr. Carlos Gonçalves, da INCM.
objectives:
Esta tese tem como objectivo a criação de um sistema inteligente para apoio ao preenchimento de reclamações no livro de reclamações electrónico implementado pelo Imprensa Nacional - Casa da Moeda (INCM). Pretende-se a criação de um classificador que, a partir da introdução pelo utente de um sumário em lingua natural, determine a entidade sobre a qual a queixa deve ser dirigida, assim como a entidade reguladora a quem apresentar a queixa. Por exemplo numa situação passada num posto de combustível, a entidade reguladora poderá variar desde a ASAE (se for um produto alimentar) até à Entidade Reguladora dos Serviços Energéticos (se tiver a ver com a venda de combustível).

Organização:
Em termos de organização, o trabalho visa as seguintes etapas: a) Levantamento do estado da arte em tarefas de classificação de texto; b) Preparação de um dataset de treino e validação a partir da base de dados de reclamações; c) treino de um modelo utilizando várias técnicas; d) Criação de um protótipo de testes com utilizadores; e) análise dos resultados; f) Escrita da tese
requirements: Recomenda-se a frequência da disciplina de Língua Natural

title: [Dissertation] A Separation-Logic Solver for Program Verification
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Recent years have witnessed a series of success stories on the application of program analysis and verification techniques to statically-typed programming languages inside world-leading software companies. The most notable example is Infer [1], a separation-logic-based tool developed inside Facebook that is aimed at lightweight bug-finding of C, C++, Java/Android, and Objective C programs. 
For program analyses to attain proper industrial acknowledgment and uptake, they need to be scalable. Program analyses achieve scalability by being compositional: that is, “the analysis result for a composite program is defined in terms of the analysis results for its parts and a means of combining them” [2]. In fact, compositionality was key for the success of Infer, which analyses millions of lines of code per day as part of Facebook’s code review pipeline. 
Separation logic [3, 4] is a form of program analysis that enables compositional program reasoning. It is at the core of Infer, where it is used for lightweight bug-finding, but it also underpins many academic tools for proving functional correctness properties of programs written in languages as different as C [5, 6], Java [6,7], OCaml [8], and JavaScript [9,10].
Modern separation logic engines use separation logic formulas to represent the state of their input programs and sophisticated pattern matching techniques to solve entailments between these formulas. These techniques are often described in the literature in a non-deterministic fashion, meaning that they cannot be directly used to guide efficient implementations. 

At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [9,10], the first separation-logic-based tool for JavaScript verification. JaVerT has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [11], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [12]. 

JaVerT uses a custom-made separation logic solver based on pattern matching as part of its core symbolic execution engine. The **goal** of this project is to re-design the existing solver using recent ideas on sub-goal ordering [13,14] coming from logic programming research, where pattern matching is routinely used in the context of unification [15]. We expect the new solver to exhibit better performance than the existing one, and, more importantly, to be based on a clear well-defined algorithm that others can follow. 

This project combines theory and practice. The limitations of the proposed algorithm are to be precisely understood and formally characterised and the resulting implementation must be thoroughly evaluated using appropriate test suites (example: the separation logic benchmarks from the 2014 competition [16]). 

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial. Good projects may lead to a publication in a verification/PL venue.

[1] C. Calcagno et al. Infer: Automatic Program Verifier for Memory Safety of C Programs. NASA FM’19. 
[2] P. O’Hearn. Continuous Reasoning: Scaling the Impact of Formal Methods. LICS’18. 
[3] J. Reynolds. Separation Logic: a Logic for Shared Mutable Data Structures. LICS’02. 
[4] S. Ishtiaq et al. BI as an Assertion Language for Mutable Data Structures. POPL’01. 
[5] M. Botincan et al. Separation Logic Verification of C Programs with an SMT Solver. ENCS’09. 
[6] B. Jacobs et al. Verifast: A Powerful, Sound, Predictable, Fast Verifier for C and Java. NASA FM’11. 
[7] D. Distefano. jStar: Towards Practical Verification for Java. OOPSLA’08. 
[8] R. Krebbers et al. Interactive Proofs in Higher Order Concurrent Separation Logic. POPL’17. 
[9] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT: JavaScript Verification Toolchain. POPL’18. 
[10] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT 2.0: Compositional Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. POPL’19.  
[11] https://research.fb.com/announcing-the-winners-of-the-facebook-continuous-reasoning-research-awards/
[12] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/encryption-sdk/latest/developer-guide/introduction.html
[13] Mistral Contrastin et al. Automatic Reordering for Dataflow Safety for Datalog. PPDP’18. 
[14] E. Rohwedder et al. Mode and Termination Checking for Higher-Order Logic Programs. ESOP’96. 
[15] J. Robinson. A Machine-Oriented Logic Based on the Resolution Principle. Journal of the ACM. 
[16] https://github.com/mihasighi/smtcomp14-sl/
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: DISSERTAÇÂO: Extracting Informative Content from Web Pages
objectives:
Many application nowadays rely on information obtained from websites. A common example is a price comparison service, such as "Price Wise" (https://blog.mozilla.org/firefox/price-wise/).  However, although this is fairly simple if you want to extract specific information (such as prices) from specific websites (such as amazon.com), the problem gets much more complex on more general cases.

This dissertation will focus on a subtask related to extracting information from the Web: detecting the main content on a Website. For example, when looking at blog post, much of the content is not actually relevant information but advertisements, user comments. navigational menus, etc. The question is, therefore, how do you separate the actual information from all that spurious data.

In this work, you will develop an automated solution to do just that.
requirements: The background required can be found in the "Information Processing and Retrieval" and other related courses. The student should be comfortable with math and statistics.

title: Dissertação: Intelligent Student Feedback
objectives: The objective is to develop a system that will automatically help students with debugging their software projects (in courses such as IAED or ASA).  As of now, students only get very limited feedback when submitting their projects. Upon submission,  systems such as Mooshak only tell the student which tests have passed and which have failed. However, it is often difficult for the student to find the actual bug based on this information alone. The objective of this thesis will be to develop a system that will provide the students with a more informative test case that will help the students to debug the project.

title: Projecto - MeteoTecnico Responsive
observations:
As exigências de cidadania criaram a necessidade de apresentar, de forma fácil e clara, informação ambiental detalhadao", em dispositivos móveis com ecrãs de tamanho e resolução variados. Correntemente, o site que disponibiliza tal informação (http://meteo.tecnico.ulisboa.pt ) apresenta-a de forma demasiado complexa e fechada e não contempla as especificidades dos dispositivos.
Numa óptica centrada no utilizador, pretende-se disponibilizar a informação ajustando os conteúdos ao nível de exigência dos utilizadores e aos dispositivos por eles usados, identificando os problemas que actualmente aquele site apresenta e propondo e testando soluções para o mesmo.
objectives:
Criar uma solução para a apresentação de informação apresentada pelo site meteo.tecnico.ulisboa.pt que se adapte automaticamente ao tamanho e resolução dos dispositivos móveis e seja apresentada de uma forma eficaz e simples ao utilizador leigo.
Identificar oportunidades de serviços adicionais (por ex., previsão do estado do tempo em deslocações de grande duração).

http://hawking.ist.utl.pt/brisson/Dissertacao/19-20/MeteoResponsive.pdf
requirements:
Interfaces Pessoa-Máquina,Visualização da Informação (opcional)
Tecnologias: HTML5, CSS, Javascript, ThreeJS/WebGL

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertation: Force Field calculation for Biomolecules
observations: Orientação Externa: Doutor Francisco Fernandes (francisco.fernandes@ist.utl.pt) com 50%
objectives:
Context:
At the molecular level, almost every biological function, process and interaction is guided by attraction and repulsion forces between the atoms.
Think of it as a giant pool of spherical magnets with different sizes, forces and charges.
A Force Field comprises not only these atoms’ energies, but also their type, radius, bonds, distances, angles, etc.
But to determine the direction, speed and overall movement of each atom, we need to calculate the contribution of the forces of every other atom over this one.
If we consider a system composed of thousands of atoms, this problem, as well as the time necessary to computationally calculate it, grows immensely.
Therefore, more efficient ways to solve it are required.

Goal:
This work aims to use space-partitioning techniques and data structures, such as Octrees or Bounding Volume Hierarchies, to tackle this problem in acceptable running times.
We can divide the 3D space into volumes of different sizes and store in each one the average of the forces of all the atoms inside each one.
Then, to calculate the influence of the Force Field over each atom, we can simply query the volumes where he is included into, instead of querying all the other atoms.

Description:
You will have to study and test different Computer Graphics 3D Acceleration Structures and their performance;
implement a Particle-System-like concept tool to calculate the forces over each atom and to simulate their movements across time;
come up with improvements and optimizations to the Force Field calculation method;
acceleration via GPUs is not required, but welcome.
requirements: Conhecimentos de Computação Gráfica, em particular na área de Visualização e interesse na área da Biologia

title: Dissertação: Explanation in Deep Classifiers: Application to Fraud Detection
observations:
The work will be co-supervised and carried out in collaboration with the company Feedzai.

Mariana Almeida, mariana.almeida@feedzai.com
objectives:
Context and motivation:
Machine learning has been used in many application areas (medicine, law, fraud detection, vision, education, security, and others) with tremendous impact. In this context, recent remarkable success has been achieved by deep neural networks, but these models are known for their lack of interpretability/explainability; in other words, their decisions are hard (or even impossible) to explain in terms of characteristics of the input. However, interpretability/explainability is very important in several areas, namely when these decisions affect human beings; for example, medical or financial decisions.

Understanding deep learning models is thus essential for several reasons: 1) to improve human trust on the models’ decisions, 2) for ethical reasons, ensuring that decisions are being made in a fair way, 3) for compliance reasons, making sure that recent regulations are being followed (such as GDPR and European guidelines for AI), and 4) for improving the model itself and designing more accurate solutions.


Objectives:
The goal of this thesis is to address the explainability problem in deep learning, by focusing on a specific application: fraud detection in financial transactions. The thesis will focus on recent deep learning methods, which are extremely powerful but for which more classical explainers are not suitable. The work will be done with collaboration with the company Feedzai (https://feedzai.com), which will provide access to real data and deep learning models.
requirements: Preference will be given to students with background on machine learning.

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: Faster than real time processing of aircraft dynamic model: towards enhanced airborne decision making.
observations: Orientador externo: Ricardo Reis - Embraer (rjreis@pt.embraer.com).
objectives:
As airspace becomes more congested and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) become pervasive, the need for in-flight decision systems, capable of performing automated route optimization, is increasing rapidly. Such systems integrate real time operational data together with a model of the dynamic behavior of the aircraft, which is usually simulated resorting to interpolation over tables of precomputed values. While this method is computationally very cheap, which makes it adequate to be used in in-flight systems, it also produces results with low accuracy. In the last decade, General Purpose Graphics Processing Units (GPGPUs) have become an inexpensive alternative to conventional CPU-based systems, as they are able to perform complex numerical computations, fitting the vector processing paradigm, at a fraction of the runtime. The proposed work consist of implementing a dynamic aircraft behavior model [1], for the Lockheed Martin F16 aircraft, in a GPGPU as a means to significantly increase accuracy, while still ensuring small computation times. An important aspect to be considered in this implementation is its integration in a real-time system, where computation time is budgeted and therefore it should be possible to adjust the tradeoff between accuracy and computation time. This work will be advised in collaboration with Embraer.

[1] "Aircraft Control and Simulation" Brian L.Stevens & Frank L. Lewis; 1992, J. Wiley & Sons - 1ª Edition.
requirements: The student must have obtained a minimum grade of 16 (in 20) on each of the following courses: Linear Algebra (Algebra Linear) and Analysis and Synthesis of Algorithms (Análise e Síntese de Algoritmos).

title: Dissertation: Adapting the Citizen Card to Post-Quantum Cryptography
objectives: The citizen card uses the RSA cryptosystem for signatures and authentication which is insecure in a (hypothetical) future with powerful enough quantum computing. The goal of the project is to study how can the citizen card be extended with post-quantum cryptosystems using the RSA private information in the card. The implementation must take into account the constraints of the smart card (EEPROM, RAM, processing, etc.). Different candidates to the NIST's Post-Quantum Cryptography Standardization project may be studied and compared to evaluate it's feasability to be implemented in the smart card.»

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: [Project] Hands-free input for head-mounted displays using head- and eye-data
observations: This project will be co-supervised by Dr Ian Oakley from the Interactions Lab at the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology.
objectives: Virtual- and Augmented-Reality (VR, AR) headsets are an emerging form factor and device platform suitable for applications from medicine to industry. While current devices are unified in providing rich, high resolution graphics, there is less consensus on how users should interact with them while performing work-related activities - situations where the use of gestures of hand-held controllers is not always appropriate. As such, this project will look to develop new hands-free input techniques using gaze (head- and/or eye-data), enabling input to AR and VR headsets even when the user's hands are occupied.

1. Strong programming skills in Java, C#, etc.2. Interest in Signal Processing and/or Sensor Fusion
3. Interest or experience in Unity
4. Basic understanding of usability studies

supervisors: Teresa Maria Sá Ferreira Vazão Vasques (100%)
title: Dissertação: Um dia no museu da computaçao do Técnico - IoT para suporte a jogos "escape the room" e "peddy paper"
location: INESC-ID (Alameda ou Taguspark). Testes de campo realizados no campus do Taguspark, nas instações do museu
observations:
Possibilidade de atribuição de bolsa, dependendo da qualidade do trabalho desenvolvido no projeto de tese.

Orientador: Teresa Vazão: teresa.vazao@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
o Taguspark dispõem dum museu de Ciência da Computação, que se encontra em fase de desenvolvimento, existindo à data um espólio significativo de peças, que resultou duma primeira exposição realizada em 2012.
 
Uma primeira tese, que se encontra a terminar, concebeu um sistema de sensorização e localização para o museu que possibilite a criação duma experiência interativa diferenciadora. Em termos de desenvolvimento, dessa tese resultou um sistema de localização que oferece aos visitantes do museu a informação adequada à sua localização, tendo por base apenas uma aplicação móvel a instalar nos telemóveis dos visitantes.

Na presente tese pretende-se evoluir o sistema, para permitir que o museu suporte a realização de jogos, em que o visitante interage com o espaço físico através de sensorização e a evolução do jogo é controlada por esta interação. Estão previstos dois tipos de jogos: “escape the room “ e “peddy-papers”.
requirements: Solidos conhecimentos de redes, programação e sistemas Linux (Raspberry Pi).

supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: [Dissertação] De música para uma sequência de imagens
observations: Para mais informação contactar H. Sofia Pinto sofia(at)inesc-id.pt (http://ontol.inesc-id.pt/~sofia/) ou Nuno Correia Nuno Correia nmc(at)fct.unl.pt (http://ctp.di.fct.unl.pt/~nmc/)
objectives:
Computational Creativity is an interesting topic in AI. While the discussion of whether machines can be creative and create creative artifacts is heated and fierce we focus on Inspiration: we pick an artifact deemed and widely recognized as highly creative because it was created by a human expert in some artistic form and transform it in an artifact in another artistic field. 
In this Thesis we aim to explore the translation of music and its temporal dimension into a sequence of images that is aligned with that music and visually illustrates it. Examples, created by humans are
https://youtu.be/0S43IwBF0uM (Directed by Michel Gondry https://www.quora.com/How-was-this-video-technique-from-The-Chemical-Brothers-Star-Guitar-created)

title: [Dissertação] Ser Músico em Portugal - ontologia e sistema de informação
observations:
Este projecto será uma colaboração entre o grupo IDSS (https://idss.inesc-id.pt/) do INESC-ID e o CESEM (http://cesem.fcsh.unl.pt/) da FCSH.
Já existe uma tese em desenvolvimento com este tema, destinando-se esta a dar-lhe seguimento...
objectives: O projecto "Ser músico em Portugal" pretende reunir informação dispersa por várias bases de dados sobre músicos e profissionais relacionados com a música, que tenham vivido em Lisboa entre 1750 e 1985, oferecendo um serviço único de pesquisa e acesso a essa informação. Como essas bases de dados são diferentes (e deverão poder continuar a ser utilizadas independentemente) a solução para este problema deverá passar pela definição de uma ontologia. Neste trabalho, pretende-se a criação dessa ontologia, e de uma aplicação ou solução que permita a exploração da mesma.
