title: [Dissertation] Artificial Intelligence for Bridges
observations:
- Motivation -
Most design methods in civil engineering are computationally complex reducing the possibility of testing many different choices for a given project. AI systems, mainly machine learning, can help by creating learning machines, e.g. deep learning methods, that can provide a fast approximation of the structural constraints and properties of each design. 
Also, during monitoring of a structure there are not enough sensors to accurately predict and detect damages. Again AI system can be used to learn an inverse model to predict the source of the problem.

- Goals -
Study different neural network architectures suited to represent civil engineering behaviors in a precise way.
Develop a case study for the design of simple overpasses with multiple pillars and use AI system to provide a fast and reliable estimation of the properties.

- References –
[1] Chang, C. M., Lin, T. K., & Chang, C. W. (2018). Applications of neural network models for structural health monitoring based on derived modal properties. Measurement, 129, 457-470.
[2] Shu, J., Zhang, Z., Gonzalez, I., & Karoumi, R. (2013). The application of a damage detection method using Artificial Neural Network and train-induced vibrations on a simplified railway bridge model. Engineering structures, 52, 408-421.
[4] Lehký, D., Slowik, O., & Novák, D. (2018). Reliability-based design: Artificial neural networks and double-loop reliability-based optimization approaches. Advances in Engineering Software, 117, 123-135.
[3] Salehi, H., & Burgueño, R. (2018). Emerging artificial intelligence methods in structural engineering. Engineering Structures, 171, 170-189.
[5] Fathalla, E., Tanaka, Y., & Maekawa, K. (2018). Remaining fatigue life assessment of in-service road bridge decks based upon artificial neural networks. Engineering Structures, 171, 602-616.
[6] Padil, K. H., Bakhary, N., & Hao, H. (2017). The use of a non-probabilistic artificial neural network to consider uncertainties in vibration-based-damage detection. Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing, 83, 194-209.
objectives: This work focus on the study and development of artificial intelligence tools for helping the design and monitoring of complex civil engineering structures such as bridges and floating structures.
requirements: The student needs to have very good programming skills, knowledge of machine learning methods, and interest in novel machine learning approaches.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação: Método Híbrido para Resolução de PDEs
observations: Co-orientação externa: Prof. Juan Acebron, ISCTE (juan.acebron@gmail.com)
objectives:
Na atualidade um dos métodos mais utilizados na resolução de equações em derivadas parciais (PDE) é o método de elementos finitos (FEM). Na sua implementação numérica é preciso gerar uma malha computacional, discretizar o problema dado e resolver um problema de álgebra linear composto pelos nós do problema discretizado. A natureza global do método numérico impede calcular a solução do problema em pontos individuais no interior do domínio de definição do problema, e portanto para problemas de grande escala e geometria complexas, a execução do algoritmo numérico em máquinas massivamente paralelas sofre de problemas sérios de perda de escalabilidade. Isto é devido ao elevado custo de comunicação entre os diferentes cores envolvidos. Uma alternativa de sucesso consiste em utilizar algoritmos numéricos baseados em métodos probabilísticos. Estes métodos por serem naturalmente paralelos permitem superar a limitação anteriormente mencionada. Além disso permitem calcular a solução em pontos individuais do domínio sem precisar de gerar uma malha computacional onde resolver o problema completo. No entanto, devido à sua lenta convergência não é possível serem utilizados para calcular a solução em todos os pontos do domínio.

Esta Tese tem como objetivo desenvolver um algoritmo paralelo híbrido composto pelo método Monte Carlo e o método de decomposição de domínios. A ideia será utilizar o método Monte Carlo para calcular em paralelo a solução em alguns pontos individuais do domínio especificamente escolhidos de maneira a simplificar o problema de álgebra linear original para um problema equivalente descrito por uma matriz diagonal a blocos. Isto na prática permitirá desacoplar o problema global em problemas independentes cuja resolução será posteriormente atribuída a diferentes cores que trabalharão independentemente sem necessidade de nenhuma intercomunicação. Uma vez implementado o algoritmo paralelo este será testado resolvendo problemas de grande escala de interesse em Física e Engenharia, utilizando diversas infraestruturas de supercomputação europeias.
requirements: Os estudantes interessados em realizar esta Tese de Mestrado deverão ter frequentado a cadeira de Computação Paralela e Distribuída.

title: Dissertation: Dynamic dialogue in story driven games, through player interaction and character’s states
location: This work will be developed at Grupo Inteligência Artificial para a Sociedade (GAIPS) - INESC-ID, IST-Taguspark and Laboratório de Jogos do IST- Taguspark.
observations: Work proposed by Lourenço Cortesão nº 94267
objectives:
In story driven games, dialogue has a great impact both when it comes to exposition of the story and impacting the experience of 
the player. Depending on dialogue you could make or break a story.
The purpose of this project is to develop a dialogue system, where, depending on the choices made by the player throughout the game and 
character’s state, it will dynamically adapt to the experience. With this system, a game will improve its replayability and help the player 
create a unique progression.
The objective of this development is also to understand if such a stark the difference in a standard system will improve or completely change the 
overall experience.

title: [Dissertation] You’re a Wizard (YaW)
observations: Robots are here. And they can not do much outside of controlled environments by themselves yet. Current sensing and reasoning technologies still limit their deployment in non-industrial scenarios as fully autonomous systems. However, with small contributions from human operators, a robotic system can be successfully deployed highly complex missions [1]. A previous study [2] with a robotic guide in a busy train station showed that having an operator in the loop raised task success from 29.9% to 68.1% while only requiring the operator to intervene 25% of the time. Nonetheless, teleoperation interfaces' design and functionality can limit an operator's efficiency. It is important to have a framework where it is possible to easily redesign the interface to fit the operator's needs and add extra modules as needed. Furthermore, an easy to use interface should not be limited to specific devices nor operating systems. With the previous factors in mind, we propose a ROS/ROS2 compatible web-based teleoperation framework composed of several customizable modules that can be individually loaded and arranged in the main web app.
objectives: Develop and test an intuitive interface for remote control of a robot
requirements: Good programming skills. Preferably with experience with robots.

title: Projecto: Fault-Tolerant on-Board Image Processor for Satellites
location: INESC-ID - IST/Alameda, Rua Alves Redol, 9, Lisboa
observations:
Esta tese insere-se num projecto de investigação em execução no Inesc-id:
https://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/ist14551/projs/sarrroca/
Contactos: Prof. Horácio Neto,
Prof. Rui Duarte , INESC-ID, sala 309, ext. 251
objectives:
Existe necessidade de ter sistemas capazes de operar em missões de longa duração e de grande custo (ex: incêndios, busca e salvamento, patrolhamento de fronteiras), pelo que é necessário ter sistemas de imagem robustos.
O objetivo desta tese é o desenvolvimento de um sistema para geração de imagens a bordo de um satélite ou drone com mecanismos de tolerancia a falhas. O sistema funciona com os sinais recolhidos "on-board" e explorando o paralelismo oferecido pela tecnologia reconfigurável (FPGAs).
O processamento dos sinais adquiridos pelo satélite tem um custo computacional elevado, pelo que reduzir o tempo de processamento necessário é um desafio importante e actual. Adicionalmente, o espaço é um ambiente hostil para os circuitos electrónicos, e como tal é necessário dotar os sistemas de capacidade para tolerar e recuperar de falhas.
O projecto a realizar tem como alvo um sistema que combina CPU dual-core com tecnologia reconfigurável, onde parte do algortimo executa em software e a outra parte em hardware (e.g. Xilinx Zynq).
requirements: Dá-se preferência a alunos com conhecimentos de projecto de sistemas digitais reconfiguráveis, que tenham média de curso superior a 14 valores e que queiram fazer a disciplina de IIEEC.

title: Dissertação: Testing an I-voting client using Symbolic Execution
observations:
There is a possibility of funding by means of an available research grant.

This task is part of an ongoing project that involves other researchers and students, with whom the student is expected to collaborate.

More information:
Ana Matos - ana.matos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
Nowadays, Web applications are increasingly ubiquitous, and are often a platform for performing information security sensitive tasks.  An example is the usage of i-voting (internet voting) systems for performing elections.  This raises the challenge of designing tools for developing secure code in JavaScript -- the current lingua franca for implementing client-side Web applications.

In recent years, a lot of work has been dedicated to the study of information flow security in Web applications with the double aim of preventing unauthorized parties from gaining access to classified user information or updating high integrity information.  However, the great majority of the proposed mechanisms for securing client-side Web applications target JavaScript-like languages which capture different aspects of the real language, but not the language in its whole. In previous work, we have developed the prototype of a static analysis tool that can be used to analyse JavaScript programs by targeting an intermediate language named JSIL. The tool, based on symbolic execution, is not yet usable, due to the high number of false positives that it produces.

The first aim of this thesis is to introduce a mechanism for dealing with the false positives that are singled by the tool.
The second aim of this thesis is to contribute to the verification of an existing implementation of an i-voting (internet voting) system that is based on a version of the Helios protocol.  The focus will be on providing strong guarantees of correctness of an implementation of the client, and in particular of the information flows that it encodes.  To this end, the developed static analysis tool for JavaScript will be employed as a case study.

Expected Result:
1- Development of a usable static analysis tool for JavaScript, based on a prototype, as described above.
2- Verification of an i-voting client, in order to guarantee that the implementation behaves as intended from a security standpoint.  This will be an important step of a larger project, which consists of the development of a secure and robust i-voting system to be presented to the academic community with the purpose of integrating it in Fenix.
requirements: Successful attendance of a masters-level course in security, specification, verification or quality of software or advanced programming languages.  Please contact for other possibilities.

title: [Dissertation] Pure Function Synthesis in the OutSystems Platform
observations: To be offered to student Catarina Coelho (84706)
objectives: In the OutSystems platform, business logic is implemented through action flows. Pure functions are one type of action flow that produces an output from a given set of inputs, just like functions in traditional programming languages. Unlike regular action flows, pure functions can be used within OutSystems expressions (e.g. assignments, if conditions, etc), and thus are useful for performing complex data transformations that are recurrent throughout the application. Moreover, because pure functions produce an output from a set of inputs, it makes sense to apply program synthesis techniques (e.g. programming-by-example) to synthesize such functions. The goal of this MSc thesis is to apply program synthesis techniques to facilitate the implementation of pure functions.

title: [Dissertation] smart-malloc: rethinking Linux's page management to support the new Intel Optane Persistent Memory
objectives:
The rise of new types of byte-addressable non-volatile RAM (NVRAM) memories, such as Intel’s Optane Persistent Memory, promises an exciting reality where tomorrow’s High Performance Computing (HPC) architectures will have hybrid memory architectures that combine each of these memories within the same physical address space.
This enables applications to choose where to place their pages. For instance, the application may prefer map the pages containing performance-critical data structures to NVRAM for superior performance, while other data structures may reside on NVRAM to benefit from its persistence or larger capacity.
This decision is, however, very hard to take by the application programmer in an optimal and portable way.
The goal of this thesis is to study how the operating system, namely its virtual memory manager, can monitor virtual page usage and automatically map/migrate virtual pages to the most appropriate physical memory. A novel page mapper will be designed, implemented and evaluated under relevant HPC workloads.

Some references:
https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~luisceze/publications/novos-hotos2011.pdf
https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3092273
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8048924
requirements: The student should be familiar with operating systems, computer architectures, concurrent programming.

title: Dissertation: Visual Argument
observations:
Sessões da Assembleia da República… Comentários na Internet… Redes sociais… É habitual haver discussões e trocas de opiniões. Para as compreender, que melhor forma do que as visualizar?!

Quem está a favor? Contra? Quem apoia quem? Tudo isso (e mais!) deverá ser visível na visualização. Esta implicará, claro, mostrar o texto da discussão, devidamente anotado, e “sincronizá-lo”/relacionar com o resto da visualização. Este parsing e anotação será para nós “magia”: há quem o esteja a desenvolver. O nosso desafio será decidir a melhor forma de mostrar a informação!
objectives: Desenvolver uma visualização de informação para argumentos! Case study: transcrições das sessões da AR!
requirements: Frequência da UC de Visualização de Informação

supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Projeto: Generation of Business Process Views
location: Instalações da Link Consulting (Av Dq Ávila 23, 1000-Lisboa)
observations: Esta dissertação foi proposta pelo aluno Sara Esperto (nr 83564)
objectives:
Nas organizações reais, os processos de negócio são normalmente definidos levantados por diferentes stakeholders, naturalmente cada um com necessidade específicas. Entre os stakeholders de processos de negócio mais tradicionais numa organização temos:
•	Departamento de Qualidade. Trata-se dos processos de negócio modelados de forma a evidenciar o cumprimento das normas ISO 9001. 
•	Departamento Financeiro. Trata-se de uma visão de processos de Negócio que permita a realização de custeio, ou seja saber quanto custa cada atividade realizada.
•	Departamento de Risco. Usa uma visão dos processos de negócio como forma de categorização dos riscos associados ao negócio da organização.
•	Departamento de Auditoria. Precisa dos processos de negócio para perceber o que deve ser auditado, quando e como. Em algumas “raras” organizações, este procedimento faz parte da qualidade, mas na vasta maioria é um procedimento interno e autónomo da certificação ISO 9001.
•	Departamento de negócio propriamente dita, que usa os processos não só para medir o desempenho da sua unidade, através de indicadores, mas também como forma de gestão de conhecimento entre os colaboradores da unidade.
•	Departamento de informática, no qual os processos de negócio são fundamentalmente a sequência de atividades a automatizar.

Para cada uma destas visões temos formas diferentes de pensar processos, formas diferentes de pensar o que são atividades e também diferentes níveis de detalhe necessário. Tudo isto resulta que, naturalmente existem diferentes visões de processos da mesma organização, frequentemente tão díspares que se tornam inconciliáveis entre si.

Com esta dissertação pretende-se aplicar e explorar os princípios de modelação de processos “multi dimensionais” que suportem um único modelo de processos para todos os stakeholders da organização ao problema da geração de vistas de processos de negócio, adequadas a cada stakeholder.

Concretamente pretende-se desenvolver uma solução /método para o problema da geração de diferentes vistas de um processo a partir de num modelo de processo consolidado

title: Dissertation: Non-blocking Parallel Interaction in Interactive Storytelling
objectives:
Interactive Storytelling (IS) is a form of digital entertainment in which the storyline is in great part determined by the unique interactions of each player in the narrative space of the game. The stories that result from such interactions have traditionally been made meaningful by making the system wait on certain plot point for a player choice. This work subverts this idea and explores an IS model with multiple simultaneous non-blocking narrative lines guided by the players in-game behaviour.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico.

title: Dissertação: Automatic OutSystems App Test Generation
observations: Tese em ambiente empresarial.
objectives:
Software testing and quality assurance account for a significant portion of the overall software development lifecycle. With the pressure to increase application turnaround time, shortening the development cycle, it is becoming increasingly important to be able to leverage automation to generate tests and ensure the software is high-quality, while keeping up with the increasing speed. New tools have made development faster making QA increasingly the bottleneck.

There are different classes of techniques explored to achieve this kind of automation, such as Search Based Software Testing (SBST), which apply search and optimization techniques to explore the space of possible tests, often-times leveraging Genetic Algorithms to reach an effective solutions. Other classes of techniques rely on statistical Machine Learning to identify the kinds of test cases that should be exercised. 

References
- Achievement, Open Problems and Challenges for Search-based Software Testing
- EvoSuite -- Automatic Test Generation for Java
- Machine Learning and Evolutionary Computing for GUI-based Regression Testing
- A Machine Learning Approach for Statistical Software Testing 
- https://www.mabl.com
- Diffblue Deeptest: AI for Automatic Test Generation
requirements: Interesse por Engenharia de Software, em particular testes de software.

title: Project: A mobile platform for enhancing biodiversity monitoring with citizen engagement
location: The work will be conducted at the Interactive Technologies Institute of LARSYS (http://iti.larsys.pt) in close collaboration with the research group.
observations: This project is part of a European funded research project and students might have access to research internships during the summer.
objectives: In a nutshell, people and wildlife are at serious risks, unless urgent action is taken to mitigate and hopefully reverse the loss of plants and animals on which our ecosystems depend on food, clean water, and a stable climate. In response to these challenges, several ICT research groups are looking at using IoT and sensor networks to monitor ecosystems. These sensors span from simple DIY weather stations to more complex devices capable of detecting animals and changes in biodiversity with camera traps and microphones which can process meaningful events using machine learning and data mining algorithms. However, the raw data is seldom enough for characterizing complex conditions and real-world deployment requires wider participation from the communities that live and/or work the proximities of these deployments. This project will lead to the development of a novel citizen-science mobile application which will enable users to augment and contribute to increasing the efficiency and coverage of the IoT sensor network for biodiversity monitoring.
requirements: Students should be familiar with mobile development tools and platforms, in particular, frameworks for Android and iOS (e.g. React Native, Flutter, Ionic or Xamarin), to implement and deploy interactive applications that can be used and tested in real-world conditions by users. Students should be interested in Interaction and Design and Human-Computer Interaction techniques since the development of the prototype will require conducting participatory design and evaluation sessions with end-users.

supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (50%)
title: Dissertação: Mobile Rectify: Recovering from Cyber Attacks in Mobile Applications with Backend-as-a-Service
location: Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos, INESC-ID, Alameda
observations: Proposta elaborada com o estudante Diogo Lopes Vaz, número 83446
objectives:
Nos últimos anos têm surgido novas frameworks e bibliotecas para desenvolvimento de aplicações móveis que permitem a integração com serviços remotos através de uma API. Estes serviços remotos, que são executados no backend da aplicação móvel, permitem guardar o estado da aplicação móvel, enviar notificações, autenticar utilizadores, utilizar recursos computacionais, entre outros. Estes backend podem ser desenvolvidos em diferentes frameworks e linguagens de programação. Para facilitar o desenvolvimento destes serviços remotos surgiram novas plataformas que permitem configurar um backend sem a complexidade de desenvolver um servidor de raiz. Alguns exemplos deste tipo de plataformas são o Firebase (Google), Parse (open source), Deployd, Back4app, entre outras. 

Através do uso de um backend as aplicações móveis podem distribuir o seu estado entre dispositivo móvel e servidor remoto. Esta distribuição do estado da aplicação permite que um atacante, ao explorar uma vulnerabilidade do dispositivo móvel, consiga propagar os efeitos do seu ataque para o servidor remoto. Quando tal acontece é necessário proceder a recuperação da intrusão, ou seja, tendo em conta as acções do atacante no dispositivo móvel é necessário corrigir o estado tanto na aplicação móvel como no backend. Para tal é necessário usar um mecanismo que permita associar as ações do atacante no telemóvel às chamadas remotas para o backend. Este tipo de associação pode ser feito através do uso de metadados que são associados a cada pedido da aplicação móvel, contudo, em alguns casos tal não é possível, visto que o backend permite modificações ao seu código fonte. Uma alternativa passa por usar algoritmos de classificação (Machine Learning) que permitam identificar as operações remotas que são causados por operações na aplicação móvel. 

Com este projecto pretende-se desenvolver um mecanismo que permita:
  - detectar padrões de comunicação entre aplicações móveis e back-end (FireBase);
  - aprender a ligação entre pedidos à aplicação e os comandos no back-end;
  - fazer a recuperação de intrusões através da execução de operações que corrijam o estado afetado pelo ataque.


Referências:

David Matos, Miguel Pardal, and Miguel Correia. Rectify: Black-Box Intrusion Recovery in PaaS Clouds. In Proceedings of the 2017 ACM/IFIP/USENIX International Middleware Conference, Dec. 2017.
requirements:
Realização do projeto em tempo integral, 40 horas/semana (excepto cadeiras do curso).Boa classificação em bases de dados, sistemas distribuídos, segurança
Recomendação: computação móvel

title: [Projecto] A graph algorithm library based on succinct data structures
observations: Joana Modesto Hrotko (81423) has already manifested interest on this topic.
objectives: Graphs are ubiquitous among many complex systems, where we find large and dynamic complex networks. It is therefore important to be able to not only store such graphs in compressed form, but  also to update and query them efficiently while compressed. Moreover it is fundamental that such representations allow us to implement most algorithms with minimal impact on their performance. The aim is then to define a sound API that graph representations must satisfy in order to allow the implementation of common algorithms, to implement a library exposing that API on top of succinct graph representations, namely on top of k^2-trees, and to evaluate the performance of traditional graph algorithms implemented on top of the developed library.
requirements: Knowledge and interest on algorithms and data structures.

title: Dissertação: QualLingo? – Automatizar o Processo de Tradução e Controlo de Qualidade de Textos Técnicos em Lingua Natural
objectives:
A Traductanet uma agência de tradução internacional criada há mais de 30 anos, especializada em tradução técnica para diferentes indústrias, localização de software e de websites, gestão de terminologia e interpretação. A Traductanet trabalha com as principais línguas do mundo, abrangendo um amplo leque de combinações linguísticas e as principais áreas de especialização, a fim de responder, através de uma tradução especializada de qualidade, às crescentes necessidades dos seus clientes num contexto globalizado. Para mais detalhes, ver https://www.traductanet.pt/.

Pretende-se com este projeto a realização de atividades de investigação considerando as seguintes áreas emergentes: processamento de língua natural (Natural Language Processing, NLP), engenharia de linguagens (Software Language Engineering, SLE), e automação (não-intrusiva) de processos (Robotic Process Automation, RPA).

O aluno deverá (1) analisar a atividade atual da Traductanet ao nível dos seus processos e ferramentas de trabalho; (2) analisar e investigar o estado da arte das tecnologias referidas acima, i.e., NLP, SLE e RPA; (3) identificar e discutir formas e mecanismos de reutilização e automação desta atividade, tendo em consideração as tecnologias de NLP, SLE e RPA; (4) propor e implementar um protótipo que demonstre uma melhoria do processo; e (5) avaliar os resultados em contexto controlado.

Principais resultados:
- Ferramenta computacional de demonstração
- Artigo científico

title: DISSERTAÇÃO : Process Mining From Natural Language Text
DISSERTAÇÃO: Instance Generation for Digital Forensics
objectives:
Digital Forensics concerns the area of using computer algorithms to
support judicial claims. It has been shown that several problems
in digital forensics can be mapped into several classes of well-known
artificial intelligence and automated reasoning problems.

However, due to privacy issues, the number of problem instances
publicly available is very small. In a recent study, it was shown
that only a very small minority of published papers is based on
publicly available data. Therefore, the goal of this work is to
develop new models to generate problem instances in order to
be solved by digital forensics algorithms and tools.

title: Projecto: IoT Lab Box
objectives:
Enquadramento

O DEI tem vindo a equipar um laboratório dedicado para a realização de trabalhos com integração de sensores ciber-físicos (IoT - Internt-of-Things). Atendendo à especificidade dos módulos de hardware e equipamentos usados o desenvolvimento de uma parte significativa dos trabalhos de laboratório e dos projectos irá requer o acesso à instalação do laboratório com acompanhamento presencial de um responsável, limitando a sua acessibilidade.

Objectivo

Pretende-se neste trabalho desenvolver um módulo portátil constituído por alguns sensores ciber-físicos e com várias interfaces para comunicações, a ser integrado numa pequena caixa facilmente manipulável e transportável. O objectivo final será distribuir vários destes equipamentos pelas salas de estudo do DEI para requisição pelos alunos para o desenvolvimento dos seus trabalhos, alargando assim o período de acesso à infraestrutura laboratorial.

Cada módulo será baseado na tecnologia Arduino e incluirá:
- diversos sensores ambientais - temperatura, luminosidade, qualidade do ar, etc.;
- a sua interligação a uma rede IoT - previsivelmente baseada em WiFi e com a pilha de protocolos adequada para suportar, pelo menos, padrões de utilização publish-subscribe;
- interface Bluetooth Low Energy para interacção de proximidade com smartphone.

Será também de considerar a inclusão de equipamentos de medida na "Lab Box" (do tipo PisoScope, ou outros semelhantes).
requirements: Interesse por sistemas e redes ciber-físicos e da IoT.

title: Dissertation: Making Tor robust against traffic correlation attacks by providing K-anonymity
observations: This work will be performed in collaboration with Diogo Barradas, a PhD student with expertise in traffic analysis, censorship resistance systems, and machine learning.
objectives:
The Tor anonymity network is currently the mostly used system for anonymous communication over the Internet. However, despite its sophisticated defenses, Tor users may be subject to deanonymization attacks based on traffic correlation. This occurs for two main reasons. On the one hand, due to the unicast nature of Tor circuits, there is a one-to-one correspondence between the volume of traffic exchanged between senders and receivers. On the other hand, the fact that the Tor relay nodes forward the circuit packets along a fixed route and without introducing delays or packet reordering introduces a timing side-channel that can be exploited by correlating the inter-packet arrival times at the sender and receiver endpoints. Unfortunately, as shown in recent studies, a large fraction of Tor traffic can now be captured by a small number of network providers. As a result, one can realistically assume the existence of adversaries with the ability to intercept the traffic in strategic points in Tor circuits (i.e., at entry nodes and exit nodes) and perform traffic correlation attacks in order to deanonymize a significant amount of Tor users.

The goal of this project is to build TorK a new variant of the Tor system which aims at increasing its resilience against traffic correlation attacks. Rather than establishing unicast circuits in the network, the key idea behind TorK is to enable the creation of circuits, named k-circuits, in which the exit node is linked not to one single sender, as in Tor, but to a group of K senders. Intuitively, in a k-circuit, each of the K senders will establish independent sub-circuits that share a common exit node. Of the K senders, one only will correspond to the real sender, whereas the remaining K-1 (named puppets) cooperate with the real sender in generating fake traffic towards the exit node. The exit node will take care to filter out the fake traffic and forward to the destination only the traffic received by the real sender. The traffic generated by the puppets with share the similar properties of the real sender such that an adversary with the ability to intercept the communication of all the K sub-circuits will not be able to identify which of the senders is the actual interlocutor of the destination. In summary, TorK will make Tor robust against traffic correlation attacks by providing K-sender anonymity. In order to guarantee indistinguishability of sub-circuits, we will develop traffic shaping techniques based on censorship-resistance protocols developed recently by our group. TorK will be implemented based on the Tor codebase. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. 

The mains tasks of this project will be: 1) review the related work, 2) design the TorK system, 3) implement a prototype, 4) evaluate the system through experiments, 5) write a scientific article, and 6) write a dissertation.
requirements: Interest in distributed systems, security, and machine learning. Attendance in the forensics cyber-security course.

title: Dissertation: Automated Game Instrumentation to assist Playtesting
location: This work will be developed at Grupo Inteligência Artificial para a Sociedade (GAIPS) - INESC-ID, IST-Taguspark and Laboratório de Jogos do IST- Taguspark.
observations: This work was proposed by Carolina Veloso, 83438
objectives:
Playtesting is often conducted during the video game design process to help developers improve their games, by providing insightful information about the player's behaviour, preferences, and how they interact with the game overall. In addition, playtesting is also important to access the flaws in the gameplay and to identify unclear or uninteresting sections, adding fun elements or balancing existing ones. However, obtaining quality feedback for a thorough analysis can be difficult and tedious if we rely on direct observation alone and without proper instrumentation.

The goal of this project is to study and identify which playtesting data is most pertinent to collect and, with that, design and develop an instrumentation tool that can help developers through an automated collection, tracking and testing of key player behaviours and metrics, during the gameplay, and thus significantly simplify and speed up the playtesting and data analysis process.

title: Dissertação: VfcShareLatex - Efficient Consistency for Cooperative Latex Edition
location: The work will be developed at INESC ID.
objectives:
Background:
- Collaborative writing tools are widely used and available (e.g.Overleaf, ShareLatex - https://www.sharelatex.com/).
- A problem is the speed at which “userA” sees the changes that “userB” has done.
- Thus, there are several consistency protocols that can be used for that purpose.

Goal:
- Design a module based on the consistency protocol called Vector Field Consistency (VFC) (https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-76778-7_5). 
- VFC allows updates to different parts of a document to have different priorities (e.g., depending on the relative interest of the user in the region in which the update is performed).
- Implement and improve the current version of VFC and integrate with ShareLatex. 
- Evaluate the protocol VFC in ShareLatex.
requirements: Enjoy and have adequate skills to deal with Linux and JavaScript.

title: [Dissertação] A scalable and performant permissionless blockchain
observations: Aluno: João Paulo da Costa Campos
objectives:
This thesis aims at demonstrating that a set of abstractions such as consensus, membership, or random committee assignment, can be composed to build a highly scalable, secure, and performant Blockchain. In particular, the thesis attempts to demonstrate that it is possible to achieve the following properties simultaneously: open membership, good performance on the order of tens or hundreds of transactions per second, high availability for causally consistent transactions, the possibility to have strongly consistent transactions with good performance (but may block if there is a partition), and strong fairness properties.

Time permitting, the new design will also couple the strong identities given by Trusted Execution Environments with Byzantine fault detection protocols such as PeerReview in order to detect participants that deviate from the prescribed protocol and permanently evict them from the system.

title: Dissertação: Secure Android keystore based on virtualized trusted sandboxes
observations: This work will be performed in collaboration with the University of Minho.
objectives:
Android devices are used for preserving highly sensitive personal data. To protect that data, Android uses a specific hardware technology called Arm TrustZone which helps isolate security-critical services from the rest of the operating system. Thus, even if Android is compromised by malware, e.g., by a rootkit, the secrets maintained by such services will remain properly secured. For example, for enhanced security, Android Keystore resides inside TrustZone. The Keystore is responsible for validating user credentials, handling keys for file system encryption, securing application key material, etc. However, recent attacks to TrustZone software have resulted in catastrophic losses, such as the full compromise of the Android encrypted file system, and disclosure of mobile application keys. These attacks were possible because, ironically, the software deployed by the device manufacturers inside the TrustZone contains numerous vulnerabilities that can be exploited from the Android environment itself.

The goal of this project is to build Keystone, a system that will propose an alternative architecture for hosting critical Android services such as the Keystore. Rather than deploying these services inside the TrustZone, Keystone will rely on trusted sandboxes instantiated inside Android itself where services' code and secrets will reside. To create trusted sandboxes, Keystone will leverage a tiny hypervisor, running below Android, for allocating the memory pages and scheduling the threads associated with each trusted sandbox while preventing unauthorized accesses by Android itself. This architecture allows us to preserve the same security guarantees offered by TrustZone while significantly reducing its exposure to external threats. This is because TrustZone will be used only to validate the hypervisor integrity at boot time. This project will leverage an existing hypervisor as a building block for instantiating trusted sandboxes, and use that capability for implementing a secure Keystore service inside Android. The Keystore service will be implemented in the Rust programming language, which was designed to provide better memory safety while maintaining high performance. It will be necessary to adapt Android's internal subsystems in order to seamlessly integrate the new Keystore service with existing Keystore API. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project.
requirements: Interest in Android and security. Proficient in Java programming. Willingness to learn Rust programming language.

title: Projeto: The future of radio: combining streaming services with the traditional radio
objectives: Music streaming services are here to stay - their convenience, ease of use and viability allow millions around the globe to listen not only to their favorite songs but also to discover brand new artists that match their music taste. To many music listeners, however, traditional radio is still one of their favorite ways to listen to music, due to the human element of the company that is lost when using streaming services. Besides, traditional radio allows a quick obtainment of information during the broadcast, such as news, traffic information, and meteorology. We believe that the future of radio is to bring together the best aspects of each solution: the convenience of being able to choose what we want to hear from streaming services, and the company and information that a broadcaster allows on traditional radio stations. For this matter, we will study and develop a solution that aims to please those who love to listen to music.
requirements: Mobile application development, enterprenership.

title: [Dissertação] GroupDynamics: Agentes em jogos de grupo
objectives:
Nos dias de hoje, existem diversas ferramentas que permitem reconhecer pessoas e suas expressões faciais. O uso destas ferramentas permite adicionar uma maior dimensão à interacção social com agentes sejam eles robóticos ou virtuais. Nomeadamente, tornou-se possível a criação de agentes com mecanismos sociais que conduzem a interacções mais positivas. No entanto, a maioria dos casos de usos destas ferramentas focam-se em interacções entre duas entidades: uma pessoa e um agente. No entanto, com o avanço da IA, existe interesse em explorar contextos onde um ou mais agentes interagem em simultâneo com um grupo de pessoas. Nestas situações, o interesse dos mecanismos de emoções e sociais dos agentes deverá se focar na harmonia, coesão e capacidade do grupo. Esta tese visa  a aplicação de ferramentas de reconhecimento de ações em tarefas que envolvem vários agentes e várias pessoas com o objectivo de melhorar a experiência do grupo. Como caso de estudo irá ser utilizado um jogo colaborativo com equipas mistas de agentes (eventualmente robôs) e pessoas.
Em termos de organização, o trabalho visa as seguintes etapas: a) Levantamento do estado da arte em ferramentas de reconhecimento de ações b) Escolha dos algoritmos (ou combinação de algoritmos) mais adequados; c) Proposta e implementação de um modelo de interação social focado na dinâmica de grupos (que deverá incluir extensões aos algoritmos estudados, ou a implementação de um algoritmo ainda não utilizado) ; d) Realização de um estudo concreto  sobre a abordagem utilizada e análise dos resultados; e) Escrita da tese.
requirements: Os alunos deverão ter feito cadeiras de inteligência artificia, e em particular agentes.

title: [Dissertation] A Live JavaScript Specification
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/
objectives:
JavaScript is the de facto programming language of the Web. Not only is it widely used for client-side programming [1], but it is also used for programming server-side applications via Node.js and it even runs on small embedded devices. 

To guarantee that JavaScript programs behave consistently across all platforms, the major browser vendors very early agreed to standardise the language, creating the ECMAScript standard [2]. The ECMAScript standard, currently in its 10th edition, is a long, complex document, written in English, which describes the syntax and semantics of JavaScript. It is written as if it were the pseudo-code of a JavaScript interpreter in that it describes each statement of the language operationally, detailing each step of the evaluation. 

All the major JavaScript stakeholders (browser vendors, web security companies, governmental agencies, international research groups, etc) accept the ECMAScript standard to be the canonical version of the language and try to conform to it as closely as possible in their own implementations and models. This makes the ECMAScript standard one of the cornerstones of the internet of today. Despite its importance, the ECMAScript standard is in constant change. In fact, the ECMA Committee holds various meetings during the year to discuss modifications and additions to the standard in response to requests from the JavaScript community. These modifications and additions must then be propagated to the implementations of the language, which is often highly non-trivial as these implementations rely on various optimisation strategies in order to be as performant as possible [3,4]. 

The **goal** of this project is to design and implement a mechanism to semi-automatically generate an executable version of the standard, the Live JavaScript Specification, from its official textual description. The Live JavaScript Specification will be primarily used as an oracle to test other implementations of the language, thereby contributing to the effort of making JavaScript run uniformly and correctly across all platforms. Further applications can also be envisaged; for instance, one could use the Live JavaScript Specification as a stepping stone for automatically synthesising a correct-by-construction JavaScript compiler [5] or an official language test-suite. 

This project will consist of three main tasks. First, the student will design and implement ECMA-SL, a domain-specific language [6] for specifying and running the ECMAScript standard. Then, the student will apply rule-based natural language processing techniques to (semi)-automatically obtain a JavaScript interpreter written in ECMA-SL from the textual description of the standard. Lastly, the student will test the obtained interpreter against Test262 [8], the official JavaScript test suite. 

[1] w3techs.com/technologies/details/cp-javascript
[2] ECMAScript Committee. The 10th Edition of the ECMAScript Language Specification. ECMA. 2019.  
[3] M. Serrano. JavaScript Ahead of Time Compilation. DLS’19. 
[4] T. Rompf et al. Surgical Precision JIT Compilers. PLDI’14. 
[5] N. Jones et al. Partial Evaluation and Automatic Program Generation. Prentice Hall. 1999.
[6] M. Mernik et al. When and How to Develop Domain Specific Languages. ACM Computing Surveys. 2005.  
[7] ECMAScript Committee. Test262 test suite. ECMA. 2017.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertation: Multi-Robot Plans in Domestic Robot Scenarios: a Petri Net Software Framework for Representation and Execution
location: ISR/IST’s Intelligent Robots and Systems group (http://welcome.isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/labs/irsgroup/) - Torre Norte
observations:
The MSc thesis will be developed within the framework of the SocRob@Home project and team (https://irsgroup.isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/projects/socrob-home/), under which ISR/IST participates regularly in international robot competitions, such as RoboCup@Home (http://www.robocupathome.org) and European Robotics League (ERL) - Consumer Service Robots (https://eu-robotics.net/robotics_league/erl-consumer/about/index.html).
One ERL/RoboCup task that has been gaining increasing importance is the general purpose service robot (GPSR), that could be used as the case study for the developed work.
objectives:
Developing and implementing general-purpose robots is a very challenging task, and the better approach for the integration of all the robot system functionalities into a standard representation of a task plan is far from a consensus in the robotics community. Nevertheless, some approaches exist that enable both the actual execution of robot task plans and its expected performance analysis using mathematical tools. One such approach is based on Petri nets.
The main objective of this master thesis, is to develop and implement a Petri net software framework, that allows the representation and execution of multi-robot plans. This should include, not only the execution back end, but also, a graphical front end, that provides an user friendly interface for the visualization of: the plan design, the execution progress and the properties obtained from the model analysis. The framework should be integrated with the ROS middleware enabling the execution of plans in simulated environments, such as the ones provided by Gazebo, and in real robots.
Finally, the software framework should be tested with real robots in a domestic environment where multiple robots interact with humans to perform household chores.
requirements: Proficiency in the C++ or Python programming language is required.Experience in the Robot Operation System (ROS) framework is expected.

title: Dissertation: Hybrid Rendering Techniques for Real-Time Ray Tracing
observations: Tese a ser atribuída ao aluno Pedro Granja, número 86299.
objectives:
To develop a hybrid rendering pipeline in which rasterization and compute stages of the modern RTX GPUs work together to enable real-time visuals approaching the quality of offline path tracing. Primary visibility and shadows can be rasterized or ray traced, and reflections and ambient occlusion can be ray traced or ray marched. Global illumination, transparency, and translucency are the only features that fully require ray tracing. In order to get real-time performance, heuristics can be used in order to determine whether to render secondary effects such as shadows, reflections and refractions for individual objects considering their relevancy and cost of rendering those effects for these objects in particular case.
Fundamental references:
https://www.ea.com/seed/news/hybrid-rendering-for-real-time-ray-tracing (PICA PICA)
https://www.degruyter.com/view/j/phys.2019.17.issue-1/phys-2019-0055/phys-2019-0055.xml (Heuristicas)
requirements: AVT and 3D Programming CoursesInterest for Real-time Global Illumination

title: [Dissertation] A Formal Semantics of JavaScript Regular Expressions
observations:
More information:
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/
objectives:
JavaScript is the most widespread dynamic language [1]. It is the de facto language for client-side web applications; it is used for server-side scripting with Node.js and it even runs on small embedded devices. JavaScript regular expressions are an essential part of the language. They are often used for parsing user input and messages coming from the network and they play a key role in securing Web applications. In fact, JS developers commonly rely on regular expressions to write complex string sanitisers to prevent a variety of security attacks, such as cross site scripting (XSS) and cross site request forgery [2]. 

The behaviour of JS regular expressions is specified in the ECMAScript Standard (version 10) [3]. The JS standard is a long, complex document, written in English, about 900 pages long. Furthermore, it keeps growing every year in response to the ever-growing demand of the JavaScript community. Hence, understanding the exact behaviour of JavaScript regular expressions is becoming harder to achieve, whilst new business and cyber-security challenges make it of escalating importance. 

The goal of this thesis is to design a denotational semantics for JavaScript regular expressions and use it to guide the development of an accompanying reference interpreter written in purely functional style. Given the absence of side-effects, the obtained reference interpreter will be amenable to axiomatic reasoning in the style of [4], meaning that one can use the reference interpreter to prove properties of JavaScript regular expressions, such as the correctness of string sanitisers.

The thesis will consist of three main tasks. First, the student will design a denotational semantics of JavaScript regular expressions. Then, the student will develop a reference interpreter matching to the designed semantics and test it against Test262 [5], the official JavaScript test suite. Finally, the student will use the resulting interpreter to prove the correctness of string sanitisers using simple equational reasoning [6].

 
[1] w3techs.com/technologies/details/cp-javascript
[3] ECMAScript Committee. The 10th Edition of the ECMAScript Language Specification. ECMA. 2019.  
[4] J. Gibbons et al. Just Do It: Simple Monadic Equational Reasoning. ICFP’11. 
[5] ECMAScript Committee. Test262 test suite. ECMA. 2017.
[6] G. Gibbons. Calculating Functional Programs. Technical Report.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: Dissertação: Client-side Web Security
objectives:
A segurança web é vista hoje em dia como um problema da aplicação/servidor, mas alguns desses problemas podem ser detectados e/ou resolvidos se o cliente/browser participar nesse processo de monitorização. Exemplo desses são alguns plugins que permitem validar a não existência de ataques de man-in-the-middle.

O objectivo desta tese é estudar os mecanismos existentes que permitem a um cliente monitorizar uma sessão bem como investigar técnicas que permitam detectar ataques e aplicar contra-medidas em caso de detecção.
requirements: Segurança em Software.

title: Dissertação: Gestão de Réplicas na Periferia da Rede
observations: Este tema já foi acordado com o aluno Leonardo Epifânio (83496/ ist424799)
objectives:
Com o aumento do número de dispositivos que operam na periferia da
rede (telemóveis inteligentes, electrodomésticos inteligentes,
encaminhadores programáveis, etc) e com o aumento da capacidade
computacional destes dispositivos, existe uma necessidade crescente
de executar operações na periferia da rede de forma a reduzir a
latência para os utilizadores e a carga imposta nos servidores
colocados na nuvem.  Esta computação pode ser realizada nos próprios
dispositivos ou em pequenos centros de dados construídos para o efeito
(cloudlets).

Uma vez que os cloudlets terão menos capacidade de armazenamento que
os centros de dados colocados na nuvem, estes necessitam de suportar
replicaçao parcial. Para além disso, as réplicas de um dado item podem
ser criadas ou apagadas dinamicamente, em função dos padrões de acesso
dos utilizadores.

O objectivo desta tese é desenvolver políticas e mecanismos para
decidir em que momentos é que deve ser criada uma réplica de um dado
item num dado cloudlet e para decidir em que momentos essa réplica
deve ser desactivada. As políticas a desenvolver devem ter em conta os
padrões de acesso dos clientes e a latência observada entre as
réplicas. Em particular, os custos associados a criar uma nova réplica
devem ser ponderados em função dos ganhos que podem resultar de evitar
o acesso a réplicas colocadas em cloudlets mais distantes.

O plano de trabalho consiste nas seguintes fases:

- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.

- Concepção e concretização de mecanismos que suportem a criação e
  remoção de réplicas de dados nas cloudlets.

- Avaliação experimental da solução proposta.

Os resultados esperados são os seguintes:

- Relatório com o levantamento e análise do estado da arte.

- Um conjunto de novas técnicas para gerir o ciclo de vidas das
  réplicas dos dados na periferia da rede.

- Uma avaliação destas técnicas usando um protótipo.

- Um artigo científico descrevendo estas contribuições.

- Uma dissertação de mestrado.
requirements: O candidato teve ter bons conhecimentos de sistemas distribuídos. A frequência da disciplina de DAD é aconselhada.

title: Dissertação: Graceful Crashing of Security Vulnerabilities
objectives:
Automatically repairing security vulnerabilities has the potential to secure a software system against unknown/known attacks. We propose to do that by leveraging a three phase approach. First, we will use (non-malicious) executions of the system to learn a model of what constitutes normal behaviour. This will be done using work from the qualitative reasoning world as well as program invariants in order to capture such behaviour. At run-time, execution that fall outside of expected behaviour will lead to the program to terminate the execution and notify the developers (e.g., via a PR) of an issue.

The outcome of this thesis is an artifact that will help during the learning and deployment phase. Ideally, the tool would integrate a version control management systems (such as github) in order to open an issue when potential attacks are observed.
requirements: Segurança em Software.

supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
title: [Dissertação] Influence Analysis in Twitter using Streams
observations: Para mais informação contactar H. Sofia Pinto sofia(at)inesc-id.pt (http://ontol.inesc-id.pt/~sofia/) ou Alexandre Francisco aplf(at)inesc-id.pt (https://web.ist.utl.pt/aplf/)
objectives: Web-based social relations mirror several known phenomenons identified by Social Sciences, such as Influence and Homophily. Social circles are inferable from those relations and there are already solutions to find the underlying sentiment of social interactions. In previous work we have conducted an empirical study that combined Network Science and Sentiment Analysis techniques for reasoning about Sentiment dynamics at cluster level and analyzed the role of Social Influence on Sentiment contagion, based on large data sets extracted from Twitter. We found that clusters tend to be neutral for long ranges of time, but denote volatile bursts of sentiment polarity locally over time. In those moments of polarized sentiment homogeneity, there is evidence of an increased, but not strong, chance of one sharing the same overall sentiment that prevails on the cluster to which he belong. The aim of this thesis is to extend this approach beyond sentiment analysis, namely for analyzing opinion mining, information spreading and popularity, and to deal with data streams in order to detect patterns and events in near real time. The experimental evaluation will rely on challenges and data sets already collected in several ongoing projects, such as "GoLocal: From monitoring global data streams to context-aware recommendations", http://novasearch.org/projects/golocal/, and "HATE: Correntes de ódio e inverdade? Estudo das atitudes e da prevalência de ódio e inverdade em debates políticos através de comentários a notícias online, posts e tweets", https://www.ics.ulisboa.pt/projeto/correntes-de-odio-e-inverdade-estudo-das-atitudes-e-da-prevalencia-de-odio-e-inverdade-em.

title: Dissertation: Managing Variety during Procedural Content Generation for Games
objectives:
Procedural Content Generation (PCG), i.e. how game content can be created algorithmically, is an increasingly important area and currently one of the most active topics within the software games industry and game research. An important problem in PCG is how to manage content variety during gameplay. On the one hand, we want content to repeat itself to allow players to gain mastery over the different dimensions of gameplay. On the other hand, content has to be varied enough to maintain the player engaged with the play experience. This work explores how to manage content variety based on player in-game behaviour.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertação || MedBlock: Using Blockchain in health
observations:
Mais informações vide:  https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado
Proposto  por Aluna:  Maria Inês Ribeiro Nº Aluna: 83513…
objectives:
Motivation: 

As growing costs pressure health systems, mainly due to an ageing population, the rise of the private medical service providers has been growing in Portugal.  In 2013, nearly half of Portugal’s hospitals were private. Over the last ten years, private hospitals have grown in consultations, number of beds, emergency rooms and diagnostic tests. The number of outpatient medical consultations increased steadily between 2002 and 2013, from 9,8 million to 17,6 million visits, with private hospitals accounting for 5,1 million consultations, 29% of the total. 
The growth of private health insurance, reduced waiting times and advanced technology, are among the main growth drivers for private medical service providers.
Although major private medical service providers in Portugal have an electronic reservation system, the process of booking a medical consultation is generally a tedious process and always limited to the service provider’s ecosystem. 
MedClick provides a one-stop platform to book a medical appointment in a fast and user friendly way, across multiple medical service providers. Whether on a PC, tablet or smartphone, patients will be able to conveniently browse all available booking options, based on date, location, price, insurance providers, or customer reviews and recommendations. 

On the other hand, Disruptive technologies, such as blockchain, algorithmic techniques, data analytics and semantics and innovative concepts like gamification may offer solutions to these challenges. Particularly, blockchain technology, as a decentralised, permanent, unalterable store of information can help with the archiving and trust issues, as well as provide a frictionless method for transacting with others, whereas computational intelligence found in the technological domains of algorithmic techniques, data analytics and semantic analysis may facilitate decision making and optimise work practices and procedures. 
A decentralized ledger, such as Blockchain, may be used for smart contracts (also called self-executing contracts, blockchain contracts, or digital contracts). In this format, contracts may be stored and replicated on the system and supervised by the blockchain network.
Smart contracts help you exchange money, property, shares, or anything of value in a transparent, conflict-free way while avoiding the services of a middleman. Smart contracts not only define the rules and penalties around an agreement in the same way that a traditional contract does, but also automatically enforce those obligations.

The relevance and potential impact of blockchain and smartcontrats on the domain of healthcare, and the wider socio-economic developments, is the focus of research and development, and technology transfer to the economy.
…………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Description:
MedClick is an online platform that is being implemented and is expected to be available online through a web portal and mobile apps for Android and iOS smartphones. The major functionalities are described bellow: 

 
The platform provides a common ground for several types of users: the patients, the doctors, the administrator, the contact center staff, the sales team personnel, and the insurance company

Patients are able to access the portal and immediately search for a doctor and book a medical appointment. 

In this thesis, the student will begin by surveying the state of the art technology, principles and applications of Blockchain and smartcontracts. The student will then proceed to a survey of the state of the art of healthcare applications of blockchain, and of MedClick platform.
Considering the distributed context of booking healthcare appointment, involving several healthcare providers, patients, and insurances, the the student will then propose a solution architecture to MedClick based on blockchain and smartcontract, and develop and validate it in pilot project.
requirements:
Expected results: 1 MedClick blockchain and smartcontract Architecture specification
2. MedClick prototype implementation
3. Paper Publication.

title: Dissertação - Occlusion Culling Techniques for Mobile
observations: Parceria com a Samsung Research UK
objectives:
Objectives: Analysis and comparison of state of art, and if possible a novel approach.

Description: Occlusion culling  aims to disable rendering of objects that are not seen by the camera as they are obscured by other objects. There has been extensive prior art over the years to tackle this problem (eg. Coherent Hierarchical Culling, BSP, PVS, Portals, Anti-Portals, Hierarchical Z-Buffer Occlusion Culling, etc.). In most recent examples, Umbra has developed a custom world editor that processes the static world geometry as a polygon soup, voxelizes and subdivides the scene into view cells and generates a portal graph and cell potentially visible sets (PVS) for the entire scene. The exported data is store in a database called the Tome which is used at runtime to perform camera and region queries on the client side via the Umbra API. To account for dynamic geometry, the visibility queries can provide a conservative depth buffer (with the use of an in-house rasterizer) against which dynamic occluders can be tested quickly. The aim of this work is to investigate on algorithms and techniques that are suitable for mobile.
requirements: Conhecimentos de Computação Gráfica e programação de dispositivos móveis

O objectivo deste trabalho é a implementação de um acelerador para obtenção de imagens de satélites ou UAVs. Atualmente os algritmos que produzem imagens de maior qualidade necessitam de mais tempo de processamento, levando à necessidade de desenvolvimento de sistemas que permitam aumentar o desemepnho, mas que possam ir a bordo e sejam alimentados a baterias. specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: Dissertation: Automated Analysis of Ethereum Smart Contracts
objectives:
Blockchain technology has been receiving considerable attention from industry and academia, for it promises to disrupt the digital online world by enabling a democratic, open, and scalable digital economy based on decentralized distributed consensus without the intervention of third-party trusted authorities. Smart contracts, computer programs executed on top of a blockchain, are at the core of this technology, for they allow the creation of new distributed applications. Millions of smart contracts have been deployed on Ethereum, a major blockchain platform for smart contracts, and although they are seen with great potential, smart contracts have been known to have several security problems. Recent attacks on smart contracts and critical vulnerabilities discovered show us the huge financial loss they can impose on the users and warn us for the necessity of having methods that lead to secure and reliable implementations.

Over the last few years several static analysis tools have been developed specifically targeting Ethereum smart contracts. The goal of this project is to contribute to this very exciting and emerging area by extending and improving Smartbugs (https://smartbugs.github.io), our execution framework aiming at simplifying the execution of analysis tools on datasets of smart contracts.

Envisaged contributions might include: a) the creation/integration of new analyses into Smartbugs that are able to discover new vulnerabilities; b) better integration of existing tools in Smartbugs, considering aspects such as bug prioritization.
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: [Dissertation] A First-Order Solver for Program Analysis
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Program analysis and verification tools often rely on state of the art SMT solvers to discharge their core logic first order queries. The design and implementation of such solvers is an active field of research, delivering more mature and performant solvers every year [1]. Nevertheless, current solvers only support a limited number of theories, such as the theories of real arithmetic, strings, and bit-vectors. Other theories, such as the theories of sets, lists, multi-sets, and discrete maps, are still scarcely supported and mainly found in specialised solvers designed for the targeted theory. 
At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [2,3], the first separation-logic-based tool for JavaScript verification. JaVerT has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [4], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [5]. 

JaVerT has at its core a first order solver with support for the theory of real arithmetic and very limited ad-hoc support for the theories of lists and sets. This solver works by encoding the first order fragment of JaVerT logic into Z3 [6], a world-leading SMT solver developed at Microsoft Research. The **goal** of this thesis is to extend the first order solver of JaVerT with principled support for decidable fragments of the theories of sets and lists (already partially supported) and, for the first time, floating point arithmetic, strings, multi-sets, and discrete maps. 
This project combines theory and practice. The limitations of the proposed solver are to be precisely understood and formally characterised and the resulting implementation must be thoroughly evaluated using appropriate test suites.

[1] D. Monniaux. A Survey on Satisfiability Modulo Theory. CASC’16. 
[2] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT: JavaScript Verification Toolchain. POPL’18. 
[3] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT 2.0: Compositional Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. POPL’19.  
[4] https://research.fb.com/announcing-the-winners-of-the-facebook-continuous-reasoning-research-awards/
[5] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/encryption-sdk/latest/developer-guide/introduction.html
[6] L. De Moura et al. Z3: An Efficient SMT Solver. TACAS’08.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: DISSERTAÇÃO: InfoVis VR: Visualização de informação em realidade virtual
objectives:
Definir abordagens de visualização de informação adequadas é relevante para se proporcionar uma correta perceção dos dados. Tipicamente, estas visualizações são feitas em 2D e restringidas a ecrãs tradicionais. No entanto, com a utilização de dispositivos de realidade virtual temos a possibilidade de criar visualizações de mais fácil interpretação, por exemplo para dados geoespaciais ou com múltiplas dimensões, e com mais espaço disponível.

Objectivo: 
Explorar técnicas de visualização de informação que permitam aos utilizadores usufruir das vantagens oferecidas por uma configuração de realidade virtual.
Pretende-se assim desenvolver um protótipo com técnicas de visualização de informação em VR. Para isto, será utilizado um HMD como o Oculus Rift ou o HTC Vive, e o ambiente de desenvolvimento Unity3D.

specializationAreas: Architecture and Management of Information Systems
title: [Dissertação] Trusted Execution Environment support for blockchains
observations: Aluno: Tiago Romero
objectives:
Despite not having fullfiled the promise of a perfectly secure trusted execution environment, systems such as Intel SGX have the potential to significantly raise the bar for an adversary to subvert a distributed system. However, the use of these technologies require careful thought to cope with issues such as (1) intrinsic limitations namely in terms of available memory, (2) the need to have a small TCB running inside that environment, or (3) the need to find the right balance between using SGX to raise the bar for subverting the system and not relying on its correctness too much so that the system isn't easily compromised when SGX fails.

The goal of this thesis is to design and build a library of components that run inside a trusted execution environment, and where these components can easily be composed to either build a new blockchain or adapt an existing one to improve its security guarantees. Examples of such building blocks are consensus / state machine replication, group membership, or picking randomly assigned committees inside a group. To demonstrate the usefulness of this set of components, the thesis will also adapt an existing Blockchain to make use of these components.

There are existing tools and packages that already provide support to recognise handwritten mathematics (e.g. SESHAT [2]), with some even allowing its manipulation (e.g. Windows OneNote Maths Assistant [3] and Graspable Math [4])). In this project, you will explore the existing solutions and decide if/how they can be integrated into Xournal++.

supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (100%)
title: Dissertation: SEAL: Language-Independent Web Vulnerability Detection using Machine Learning
observations: Tema reservado para a aluna Alexandra Figueiredo
objectives:
Web applications are a common way of accessing services and resources. Although a large research effort has been going on for more than a decade, the security of web applications continues to be a challenging problem. An important part of the problem derives from vulnerable source code. Source code static analysis tools are a solution to find vulnerabilities, but they have two down sides. First, they are specific to a language, e.g., to PHP. Second, they have to be programmed, or at least configured manually, to deal with new types of vulnerabilities.
This thesis is part of a more ambitious project called SEAL (SEcurity progrAmming of web appLications) that aims to develop static analysis tools that solve these two problems: that allow detecting vulnerabilities in code written in different languages and that learn from examples how to detect vulnerabilities. 
To contribute to that goal, the objective of the thesis is to design a tool to detect vulnerabilities in intermediate code, for example, the code generated by the Rose compiler ( http://rosecompiler.org/ ). This compiler can generate intermediate code from code written in different languages, including PHP that is the language most used to implement web applications and the one we will consider in this thesis. 
Detection of vulnerabilities will be based on machine learning, following an approach we already explored before [MNC14, MNC16]. The idea is to have two stages. In the first, the tool will extract features from vulnerable code examples, in order to learn how to detect certain vulnerabilities. An example source of vulnerable examples is the SRD database: https://samate.nist.gov/SRD/ . In the second, the tool with detect vulnerabilities using that knowledge. This involves using reasonably simples machine learning algorithms like Naive Bayes, although more sophisticated approaches like deep learning [L+18] may be used if time permits. 
The outcome of the thesis will be a static analysis tool that analyses Rose intermediate code, extracts features from vulnerable code samples, and detects vulnerable code based on that knowledge. 
References:
[MNC14] Ibéria Medeiros, Nuno F. Neves, Miguel Correia. Automatic Detection and Correction of Web Application Vulnerabilities using Data Mining to Predict False Positives. In Proceedings of 23rd International World Wide Web Conference, 2014.
[MNC16] Ibéria Medeiros, Nuno F. Neves, Miguel Correia. DEKANT: A Static Analysis Tool that Learns to Detect Web Application Vulnerabilities. In Proceedings of the IEEE International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis (ISSTA), Jul. 2016. 
[L+18] Zhen Li et al.. VulDeePecker: A Deep Learning-Based System for Vulnerability Detection. In Proceedings of NDSS 2018.
requirements:
Courses with grade >= 14: Segurança de Software ou SIRSGood programming skills.
Interest in security.
Disponibilidade e motivação para realizar o projeto em tempo integral, 40 horas/semana (excepto cadeiras do curso).

title: Dissertação: Securing WebAssembly applications on untrusted mobile operating systems
observations: This work will be performed in collaboration with the University of Minho.
objectives:
Mobile devices are extremely popular and are used for running many data-sensitive applications, e.g., handling personal data, accessing banking services, etc. Thanks to the development of WebAssembly, an emerging browser technology, applications no longer need to be installed on a device. Instead, they can be download on-the-fly and be executed directly on the local browser. This is possible because WebAssembly allows web developers to run native C/C++ code on a webpage: this code, which is compiled to WASM, runs much faster than typical JavaScript code. Unfortunately, the sandboxing environment provided by modern browsers for WebAssembly code has not been designed for securing the application state from an adversary that can compromise the mobile operating system. For instance, if the Android OS is attacked by a rootkit, a malicious agent will be able to extract secrets and other sensitive data manipulated by the sandboxed WebAssembly application. Considering that this class of attacks to the operating system is far from uncommon and that the sophistication of WebAssembly applications will naturally lead to the processing of larger amounts of sensitive data, providing a strong line of defense mechanisms is fundamental.

The goal of this project is to build WArdian, a system that will provide a secure sandboxing mechanism for WebAssembly applications on mobile devices such that the confidentiality and integrity of applications’ runtime state does not require trusting the Android OS. Whenever the browser downloads WASM code from a website, WArdian will automatically deploy and execute it inside protected execution environments that we call WASM cages. The deployed WASM code will be able to interact with the remaining components of the webpage located in the browser's process (i.e., DOM and JavaScript code), and access to security services that will prevent specialized attacks potentially issued by an untrusted OS, e.g., tampering with the system clock, file system, or random number generation. In order to implement WASM cages, this project will leverage an existing hypervisor that enables the creation of memory-protected regions in which the OS holds no privileges. In summary, this work will entail: 1) the modification of the mobile Chrome browser and its integration with WASM cages, 2) the adaptation of an existing WASM runtime environment to work inside the WASM cages, and 3) the incorporation of secure services that will interact with Android while providing robust protections against rootkit attacks. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting implementation will be released as an open source project.

Main tasks: 1) review the related work, 2) design the WArdian system, 3) implement the system for Chrome / Android, 4) evaluate the system for real-world apps, 5) write a scientific article, and 6) write a dissertation.
requirements: Interest in mobile computing and security. Willingness to learn WASM language for WebAssembly programming.

title: Dissertation: Static Analysis of Javascript Code
objectives:
Static analysis tools are becoming increasingly adopted by industry, as they can be used to detect bugs in source code before the code ships.

The goal of this project is to explore static analysis tools and techniques for Javascript code. The goal is to implement new static analyses that can be used to detect errors in real-world Javascript code.

Areas of application will be defined together with the student, considering the student's interests. For example, a suggestion is to write a prototype that detects problems with code that uses promises, a feature added to ECMAScript 6 to provide better support for asynchrony. Promise graphs [1,2] can be used as a basis for such a prototype.
